Bit of trivia, this movie marks the third movie that a Doctor Who actor has co-starred with Stanley Tucci.As a movie, this is not a dark and suspenseful movie. It is ghoulishly mind warping. The story arcs and a fiend's task list in a mind game so twisted that a viewer might actually need to go to therapy. I am giving this series a 10, but you should only watch it if you are socially well-adjusted person.

A fascinating exploration of morality, made even better with exceptional acting. The writing is sharp and witty without being over the top. Some of the roles are kind of standard (the "as you know, Bob" stand-in for the audience), but the actors bring a fullness to them that makes them feel real.Stanley Tucci is stellar, of course, but so is the rest of the cast. David Tennant also shines in his role, one that shows how "normal" can go so wrong so fast without being preachy (ironic considering his character is a priest).The cinematography is amazing as well. The colors and framing highlight the characters and plot. The lighting director deserves an Oscar with how much the light tells the story as mu h as the writing does.

reviews.review_title: Can't believe how bad this is
reviews.content: A bunch of my favorite actors were involved in this, so I sat down and prepared for a good ride.The first scene on the train was good and tense, although it was hard to believe the indifference of the people around the girl that was being bullied.That scene was the only good scene in the entire show.From there it went downhill. Really downhill.The characters, specially the one that Tennant does, make ridiculous decisions, that no one would ever make in real life.It's like the writers were martians that never lived in the earth among humans, so they do not know how the humans behave.The mix between thriller and comedy does not work either, everything feels forced and unnatural.I don´t believe David Tennant and Stanley Tucci read the script before accepting to be in this mess.Please avoid this at all costs.

reviews.review_title: -100 is the rating this one deserves
reviews.content: I initially gave a rating of 3 after the first episode and the reduced to 2 after midway through the second and again reduced it to one by 1 by the time I was in the third episode. But after the third this one deserves something like a minus 100 for the pathetic way it's written and there's no way a show like this should waste talents like Tucci and Tennant. Some of the sequence are outrageously bad and the story arc is inclined towards how worse can it get by the time the final episode goes. The only saving grace is that this vile piece of excuse for a content is that it's limited to just four episodes. I only watched it for Tennant and Tucci to realise how sorry I was them!

Wow. What to say about Inside Man. Of course the plot is completely implausible but that's kind of the point - that ordinary people can be driven to do extra ordinary things by circumstances and sometimes life just isn't plausible! There are echoes of The League Of Gentlemen in the humour and surrealism which is no bad thing. Of course a lot of people are going to absolutely hate it - this is a real marmite tv show.Needless to say the acting is stellar - you can't really go wrong with David Tennant and Stanley Tucci in the lead roles. The supporting cast are also excellent - how you make a 15x serial killer almost lovable is an achievement!Really hope there is a second series to tie up the loose ends of season one. I suspect the vehicle can only really stand two or three seasons maximum - I doubt there are ever going to be industrial quantities of this show like they seem to always do in the US.In conclusion - this is well worth a watch but just be aware, you'll either love it or you won't!

"What's the very worst thing which could happen in each of these situations?" This was probably the question Steven Moffat asked himself when creating this jaw-droppingly brilliant drama which he might have been called 'A Series of Unfortunate Events' had someone not already used that!If you had started watching this half-way through the series you'd think you were watching complete nonsense because in just those first few hours, the worst possible outcomes really have happened and normal life for one family in this typical suburban town has escalated to a situation which the protagonists would have thought unimaginable just a few hours earlier. Not since the early seasons of 'Line of Duty' has a TV programme been so riveting.As the levels of intensity and craziness escalate, the only way to keep these situations believable is by having superb acting and all of the cast provide a natural and believable grounding allowing us to accept that what we're seeing is actually happening. The subject matter: loss of faith, murder, rape, child pornography and suicide are clearly pretty heavy so Steven Moffat treats these very sensitively and respectfully but also injects a wicked sense of humour throughout. Inside Man is the darkest of dark comedies and that humour is so necessary to make the nature of the plot palatable - not only palatable but enjoyable. Although few people don't seem to get the humour, most people do; you will therefore find this absolutely hilarious. That, along with it being totally mesmerising makes very addictive telly.

Not nearly as bad as the bad reviews would have you believe. The acting is top notch, as you would expect from the leads, ( Tucci and Tennant) the writing is fast and witty, with moral dilemmas and social angst thrown in for good measure. Tucci is our modern day Holmes, where the worst thing Conan Doyle could think of for his hero was a little drug addiction in todays jaded world we have to be morally ambiguous about our anti hero's, so Tucci's character is a wife murder, with his own Watson of sorts. Is it totally believable? Maybe not, but it is entertaining and that's what tv is supposed to be.

I have to confess to turning it off before the end of the first episode because it just became laughably unrealistic. Bloke on the train not being tackled and how did her apparent live streaming alert the police? Then the memory stick (which could have been hidden behind a book in the Church) casually discarded at home, the vicar's reaction when the porn was viewed he could easily have nipped it in the bud in two minutes - LOL and then the attack. Ludicrous.By far the best scenes were in the prison - that's what made me keep watching for as long as I did.Moffat has contributed to the destruction of Dr Who and he's outdone himself with this garbage - but of course the BBC tell us how wonderful it is....

We need season 2. It was a little bit slow, but at the end i finally understood why they are showing the priest's story. It was a great twist at the end, but i felt it unfinished.. the main character was great (2 prisoner, actually both of them) but the teacher and the journalist were a little irritating. Great story started with a huge bumm but after that i felt a little boring...but at the and was also a bumm again so it was a great serie. I loved Sherlock serie so so much, i wish they continue or make another great serie like that was. And i also hope that they will finish this serie because we need Inside man season 2!!!

I don't understand all the haters. This show was so cleverly written! It was a mild thriller, but mostly it was a psychological study! And the characters were very well played! The nonchalance of the next door cell mate, was perfect. Even the warden played his part really well. (The only way I recognized that actor was by his voice. Looks like he lost some weight, and the facial hair looks good on him.) Yes, it was a little weird and quirky, but that worked as a counterbalance to the depths of the story. I suspect the viewers that gave it a rating of 1 and 2 prefer a simpler shoot-em-up storyline.The show left me very curious to know what compelled Jefferson to murder his wife, and cut off her head.Janice was a real piece of work, and brought all of that on herself. The only thing I would have changed about the movie is her name. It should have been KAREN.

Top notch in all regards except the story, writing, and concept. Story is so poorly conceived that its credibility and believability is destroyed by the end of the first episode. It is so bad, it is impossible to be redeemed or saved in future episodes. It is difficult to understand by the writers, producers, and director could have missed such glaring flaws; but they clearly missed the boat in a huge way with this one. In this case, the story attempts to sell human reactions, judgements, and behavior that is beyond the pale of reality. As the story revealed itself, I was at first only surprised. By the end of the episode, I was angry I had wasted the time watching this embarrassing and unprofessional ....whatever it is.

When two of my all time favorite actors make a piece of improbable doo like this, I only hope next time I have to suffer through fewer episodes.I blame Stanley Tucci and David Tennant, because without them I would have given up after 15 minutes. As it stands I hate myself for sticking around til the end.What a terrible waste of a great cast. They're so good they almost pull it off. I kept asking myself why. Who. How do you make this up. And no amount of terrific acting is worth watching.It didn't have to be this way. There are a number of ways they could have fixed it. I don't know who signed on to do what, but I have to believe the ink was dry on the contracts before the last draft of the script.

reviews.review_title: Absurd but I found it a fun watch.
reviews.content: Absolutely ridiculous series of events but I think it was meant to be and therefore (at a reasonable four episodes) I thoroughly enjoyed it. Despite the plot revolving round a serious issue it was clearly a black comedy and the last episode was confirmation of that. I agree with some other reviews that the US scenes were rather more engaging than the U. K. ones and the obvious contrast between Stanley Tucci's superior acting to that of a wooden Lydia West when they were in the same scene was there for all to see. Yes, Inside Man had numerous flaws and yes, most people wouldn't act and behave as ludicrously as most of the key characters did but overall I found it fun to watch. Clearly many were not prepared to give Inside Man much of a chance which is fair enough if it didn't float your boat but on the other hand I think longer than twenty minutes viewing is needed to be able to critique it fairly.

reviews.review_title: If you view it as a Farce and NOT a serious Drama you'll get it and love it.
reviews.content: Really enjoyed this, the people who have given it a negative comment and low score just don't get it was written as a FARCE and not a serious drama !!!!We binge watched it, love the constant twists and turns, the acting was good, plenty of good laughs, drama and violence. The way the plot just shoots of in unexpected directions was brilliant !!!David Tennant and Stanley Tucci where very good as you would expect with good support from Dolly Wells, Lydia West, Lyndsey Marshal and Louis Oliver.A great performance from Atkins Estimond, who added great comedic content really clever writing adding this character.Just give it a try and don't take too seriously.

This is definitely one of the worst series I have ever watched. Nonsense plot, storyline is ridiculous and the acting by all the actors is also very bad. Best to skip watching this all together. Luckily there are only 4 episodes.The plot twists and general storyline make no sense, the dialogues and choices made by the characters in almost each scene are laughable. The character Grieff must be loosely based on Hannibal L or Sherlock H but his so-called "insights" and deducations are one-dimensional, ridiculous and the way they are presented are predictable and alsmost childish. Atkins Estimond's acting is definitely the worst of all and his role doesn't add anything. Lastly, the attempted humoristic dialogues are not funny but actually ridiculous.

I can't believe people are giving this such high ratings but the bar has been set low the last few years! It would have been more believable if he wasn't on death row! Tucci and the other guy( don't remember his name) photographic memory dude would never be granted such freedoms on death row. Also they were both laughable as supposed killers. Tennant, Tennant! I can't believe he agreed to do this! He was ok but his character arc was awful and unbelievable! Why would he go thru such lengths to protect a man from his church? They keep saying their son but it was clear they wanted you to keep guessing who. Lyndsey Marshall ( whom I've only ever seen in Rome as Cleopatra did a great job as did Dolly Wells ( whom I always get confused with Lucy Punch). Watchable but completely unbelievable.

The choices Tennant's character makes in the first episode are so ridiculous and outrageous that it just becomes unwatchable for me, it's just so infuriatingly self-sacrificial for absolutely no reason. An abysmal situation that could've easily been solved with the most basic communication- it's maddening. Perhaps this circumstance doesn't drive the rest of the show, but at this point, I don't care to find out.Not to mention the corny intro, written by a generation that doesn't really understand modern youth, and Tucci's somewhat ridiculous character intro as well. The whole thing is very Moffat in the way that it's painfully unrealistic, and not in a fun way.

I liked some acting, but the plot is so bad. It just doesn't make any sense. Maybe it was the idea to leave you fooled about what happenned and think about.But no - this show is completly idiotic there's no consistency, characters appear here and there for no reason.Suspense built on burning gas heater that they cant turn off? Wtf?That might be one of the worst ones series that I watched. Honestly I don't know at moments I thought it's just meant to be weird? Like dirk gently, where something weird happens and it'll makes sense later. But no - turns out it's just completely stupid.Don't waste your time on that.

The premise begins as something genuinely intriguing, but somehow within the span of just four episodes manages to all but abandon its premise, relegate its most interesting characters to roles all but inconsequential to the plot, while the real story devolves a farcical madcap 'thriller' replete with all the contrived tension of a plot that almost felt like it was supposed to be satirical at times. I honestly can't tell if this show was going for a more dark comedy tone, or if it held such an inflated view of its own story writing that we were supposed to be enthralled by this at face value, but personally I felt it crashed and burned in a fiery wreck by episode three.

My burning question is, why didn't anybody text when calls went unanswered? Why couldn't the story have added another episode about the missing head location and the rest of the mystery that went with that? Why did the Vicar not act on the porn stick in the very beginning? Why did he act so ignorant about where the stick came from? So much poor judgement from seemingly responsible people. Or is it just poor writing? With such a great cast, I could have watched more episodes. Each story line including the troubled kid and his abusive mother could have been a story in and of themselves. I did like this a lot, but I wanted more.

I originally saw this Brillaint cast and immediately thought...this has the potential to be brilliant, but will unfortunately much more likely disappoint the heck outta me.Sad to say I was right....hard to express how disappointing this is so far. The sheer unbelievability of it all...a vicar and his wife turn into scheming cold-blooded murderers, when the entire situation would be solved by turning in the mentally disturbed pedophile with the abusive mother. The vicar's wife questions why she can't find instructions on how to kill someone on the internet with the same alacrity as if she wanted to learn how to paint the kitchen.It's the classic tale of an innocent priest defending a pedophile by claiming the usb drive full of filth was his, then throwing a math tutor down the stairs and handcuffing her in the cellar, then plotting to murder her, all to save the poor pedophile. Yup...i said all that.I gave this pointless mess a 5 for 3 reasons.#1 and 2 is David and Stanley
#3. Stanley's character says 'Everyone is a murderer. You just have to meet the right person".I truly believe every human is capable of great beauty, and great horror. It really does depend on who you meet, and who influences you the most.

A harrowing tale of the unavoidably converging paths of a vicar and a death row inmate with an uncanny ability to see what isn't there to solve mysteries and crimes.The writing and acting are brilliant. All around excellent production that'll leave you with a few WTFs escaping your lips.The story of how a vicar, through no fault of his own, can go from normalcy to committing the most dreadful of acts to protect an innocent loved one. An illustration of the lengths a parent will go to.Will the pinnings and intellect of the inmate be enough to prevent tragedy. Stick with it. It's gritty, it's graphic, and it will leave you breathless.

I'm just so confused why anyone in their right mind would make these decisions that they do in this programme.Firstly. Vicar is pranging out about a USB stick... why don't you just get rid of it?? Then this stupid maths teacher would have zero leverage. And then when the police came over to question the vicar why doesn't he just be honest about wha had happened.How was that journalist bumping into that maths teacher on the train in the UK one minute and then in an American prison the next.Don't even get me started on the carbon monoxideAlso I have never hated a character more than this stupid maths teacher.Too many things ridiculous things to list. The most frustrating programme I've ever watched.

reviews.review_title: DNF - character actions are more plot driven then logically
reviews.content: DNF - managed to get to the 3rd episode and part way through. I can see where it's heading, but there's so much frustration that I can't enjoy it. Which is a shame as there are elements that are enjoyable.A big factor in my frustration is Janice. At the beginning we get a scene where we are shown her bravery and quick wit. Fast forward a bit we then get her jumping to the worst conclusion possible (not helped by David Tennant being possibly the stupidest person in the show) which ends up in her kidnapping.The kidnapping is proceeded with her taking control of situation, manipulating and turning the vicar and his wife against each other while she remains imprisoned. And this is my problem. We are presented with her being a rational and intelligent character who acts quickly and can read people, but she failed to read the very event that lead to everything. In fact the entire story is caused by her alone and her mistaken assumption. It's just painful interactions between two to three people simply to drive the plot in the direction Moffat wanted (Ooh, my poor Moffat, what has become of you?)The inmates were enjoyable, but that was basically it.David who I usually enjoy was painful to say the least.

This series is like been written by a 5 year old!nothing makes sense and there is no explanation for anything!just made me irritated!just don't waste your time!!!!skip it!the most stupid characters I have ever seen!coming from a series junkie. I watched four episodes and I am regretting wasting my time. I just liked the actor in the prison waiting for death row. The thing about the vicar is just doesn't make sense so stupid...so if you are someone who want to watch something watchabel and enjoy their time it's not for you maybe it can work for s background audio and video in house that no one cares about it.

Loved every minute. It has a stage feel to it but when you accept that it isn't a life like reconstruction of a real event like say 10 Rillington Place it is bonkers but brilliant. There's so much crammed into every minute that you really have to concentrate hard to keep up!The one thing that seemed the most implausible was that given that there were a multitude of tools, planks of wood etc in the basement why the occupants didn't at least attempt to break a window, break down the door or attempt some other escape route.Any more or less bonkers than Silence of the Lambs? Certainly up there for me.

Managed the 1st episode just
The premise is insane. If we are to believe that David Tenant is a priest who has this moral dilemma then some time needs to be spent setting that up. Not rush straight into it.When I saw who was part of this I was really looking forward to it. But the actors have been let down by the material. It's just bad.The whole interaction with Stanley Tucci at the start is so annoying. Either explain something or don't explain it. Don't do this smug reveal of why the senator was receiving money.I so wanted this to be good but it was just bloody annoying.I will watch any old rubbish , but this was a bit insulting because it thinks it's cleverer than it is.

I gave it a 5 because at least I watched it to the end because I was intrigued but it's one of the most stupid shows I've seen. The premise is stupid, the way everyone acts (not the acting so much, the way they react to things that happen) is like a B movie, it's just absurd. Even the ending, they just add a bunch of stupid "twists?" Not sure if they are even twists really, because it's not a discovery of anything new, it's just a ridiculous way of trying to make you go "oh!" - Who walks backwards into a road 😂 who calls missing persons and the police when the math teacher doesn't turn up 🤣 - it's just not even remotely believable from start to finish.

Not sure why I'm seeing such bad reviews. I was hooked after the first episode and knew I would be bingeing the whole shabang. This is an amazing little miniseries. Twisty, thrilling and exciting. Watched it all in one go. Imagine House as a law lecturer who had committed a crime and was on death row. Don't miss out. This is 100% enjoyable crime mini series. It could have been the premise of an entire television series that had multiple seasons! Stanley Tucci and David Tenant did a fabulous job. The little scenes between 2 people are the best parts. This could also be adapted for stage. Again. Can't say enough about this interesting series.

Doctor Who, Sherlock, now this - Moffat keeps trying and keeps missing, held at bay by his own wrongly perceived cleverness. And no, giving the audience riddles nobody can bring themselves to care about doesn't make for engagement and interest.The acting is all around good, but the material they were given to work with doesn't worth the paper it was printed on.None of the characters are likable or interesting, none of them can elevate the strangely s*x-obsessed plot.The entire mess could have been avoided by asking the teacher if she really thought the kid would have proudly claim the video as his had he known what was in it.

This is a story of one bad decision after another that in real life would never happen. One top of that there's the ridiculous notion of a death row convict who happens to also be a mastermind detective with control over a international secret network and a warden who plays second fiddle to his crime busting activities. Superbly acted and riveting TV for what is the most preposterous of plot lines. Without giving anything away, I hope that the TV studios write a storyline that gives us a season 2 because this has the makings of a long running show. Tennant and Tucci are as brilliant as you'd expect, as are the other actors.

reviews.review_title: Massive talent, ridiculous plot, even worse ending. I'm being generous.
reviews.content: I don't take offense, but someone certainly should. How can you have such talented actors performing brilliantly in a production where the plot and very same premise are childishly conceived in their implausibility? Furthermore, the ending looks like a cliffhanger attempt which any half-witted viewer could find aggravating. I give it a 6 and not a -maximum- of 4 because of the performances. Often you get shows that disappoint you in the first season but find redemption in the following ones. In this case, unfortunately, it seems quite obvious that a second season would only make things worse. What a shame.

reviews.review_title: The Lure of a Clever Explanation that Never Comes
reviews.content:
I've watched this all through ( gritted teeth) waiting for the big reveal that rattles it's coming practically from the start of the show.It starts with some promise, it's unrealistic and people take some ridiculously daft options but hey , that's drama fiction for you. But then, it just lingers and drags out a story. It could have been done in 2 episodes and still provided room for a far better ending.I've given a 6 stars for Tucci, removed 3 for the abysmal ending and then added a star for the theme song, nearly as good as Peaky blinders :)
Don't watch this , you'll wait all through to find out what happens and then ........ you wont!

Well acted, story kind of cool, but how can the director, writer, and actors let major plot holes just be ignored? The son was losing his mind banging on the door but the whole time he had his phone? Like, duh! Then once he knew he had his phone, all of a sudden he didn't want to get rescued?And what kind of sound-proof house is that? You can bang on the door with a hammer and nobody hears it? If he just touched the floor joist (which were exposed) with the hammer it would have echoed throughout the house. Come on folks, you can do better than that.Seems to be a theme with netflix dramas, they obviously spend a lot of money on them but don't bother to make sure the plots make sense.

First, continue watching past the credits on the last episode. There is a topper.I loved this show! It is completely ridiculous and implausible and requires suspension of disbelief entirely BUT who cares? It was extremely well acted, continued picking up hair-raising momentum, and for me was riveting right up through the last second. I said "nuh uh!" at least one hundred times. Coming in at a tightly edited four episodes, Inside Man left me crossing my fingers for a second season! Oh please oh please! You may not like this show if you are a person who is unable to surrender to wild "what if" elaborate Agatha Christie style mysteries... but I'm sold!

I really liked this four-chapters movie. With quick turns and a 50s or 60s nostalgic style in music soundtrack, dialogues and even furniture, this mini series of the BBC enchanted me. I was a little lost at times, with the fast back-in-time narratives and the many characters, but in episode 3 and especially in episode 4 ... the suspense, dilemmas and actions glued me to the screen.At times, there is a sense of irony, and some comical situations, typical of a very British drama in every sense. Not your usual American full of police cars crime, it evolves at the right pace. Tucci is gigantic here.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Skilled acting and cinematography but the story is stupid and shallow
reviews.content: TLDR: gross things happen so we can learn about Smart Man in jail for murder.This was really uncomfortable to watch. I agree with most of the reviewers on certain individual points, even opposing ones. And I think that might be the point but I'll get back to that later. It has its tongue in cheek moments I suppose, there are certain phrases that in hindsight are clearly foreshadowing, but I definitely wouldn't call it a "light" watch, nor would I call it playful simply because there are witty conversations strewn in. Implausible? Maybe but I'm not concerned with that when it comes to television and fiction generally, though this story takes it to levels that are truly insulting to our intelligence. Also, REALLY tragic things happen! And at every possible turn people make the worst choices out of the options they had. It's absolutely unnecessarily mad and chaotic. I would rather have watched a show that conveys this idea (that everyone has the ability to harm others despite what they may think), without taking to this level of ridiculousness. I found it painful to watch, and wondered why the writer made terrible choice after terrible choice just to hammer in a "narrative". I get the impression the writer thinks most viewers are stupid and he is **Very Intelligent**.So back to my previous rambling about how the point might be to hold space for opposing views. I'm all for that if there's a cause. In the absence of a cause it lacks substance. It seems the intent was to leave the viewer feeling they should "question everything", but then we're left with nothing but conspiracies aren't we? I thought the acting and cinematography was skilled hence the 3 stars, but the story was giving ReBeL wItHoUt A cAuSe vibes which isn't generally what I'm interested in consuming or amplifying. So, zero stars added for the story itself. There are plenty of actual causes out there, we don't need to be making a mockery at the expense of real life problems. I honestly regret watching the whole thing but had hoped it would take a turn at some point. And maybe it did, but not one worth sticking through to the end for IMHO. And the more I reflect on it, the more I truly hate it. And to open the story with such a gross boy thrusting his groin, getting pleasure from making everyone squirm, just to create a chance encounter? It's a NOPE for me. So tired of shows written just for shock value.

reviews.review_title: It's not supposed to be a parody, right?
reviews.content: I kept watching just to test my patience. Outrageously unrealistic, full of gaps, inconsistencies and stupid assumptions and even stupider decisions and random events. I haven't written a review for a long time but I couldn't resist this one. So much I could say but I won't waste too many words.Teacher in the cellar: most annoying character in history, with journalist being a serious runner-up.In a parallel universe it might have potential to be a decent mystery, but definitely not in this one, not in 2022... So many better ways to show that everyone is a potential killer and anything could happen to anyone. Closer to proving that everyone is stupid. Nothing really makes sense. Ridiculous.

Plot that makes no sense whatsoever, "colorful" characters that are laughably ridiculous, tons of typical Moffat dialogue that is supposedly witty but is actually tedious and stale and drags on and on ad nauseam. The actors struggle to shape this pile of bull into a story, but fail miserably. I only have myself to blame for enduring the whole 4 hours , when it was quite clear after first 20 minutes that the required level of suspension of disbelief was beyond the utter stupidity zone. Everyone involved should be deeply embarrassed and slap themselves hard for wasting the audience time. I hear that it will be on Netflix, a decision made probably because it sounds good on paper.

reviews.review_title: Honestly Can't Believe The Low Ratings
reviews.content: This show circles around one question: is it possible for any man to be a murderer in the right circumstances? And Inside Man dances around this question brilliantly.As Stanley Tucci's character says: Anyone can be a murderer. "All it takes is a good reason and a bad day."People talking about how ridiculous the set-up situation is... THAT'S THE POINT. A man (the Vicar) found himself in the most unlikely of situations, a perfect storm, if you will. And now that man, who would seemingly never hurt another living soul, is faced with decisions he never thought he would have to face.This show is brilliant.

I see where people are being fooled into thinking theyre watching something good. They think all the misunderstandings are twists and what makes something good. But no. This is just horrible. Everyone is constantly saying "we have no choice. We're doing what we have to do." And I can think of a thousand other choices to make. If you watch it as a bunch of idiots running around and laugh at their asinine antics it's fine. But even the police and the people who are meant to be smart just don't get the situations and are just ridiculous. And I can't blame the actors because they're all so talented.

reviews.review_title: Best thing I've seen for ages
reviews.content: This is such a "marmite" situation and I can see from the other reviews it was hated by some viewers.I absolutely loved it.Stanley Tucci and his prison ward sidekick were hilarious and David Tennant gave us a great performance of unbalanced and irrational behavior in a very amusing way.I loved the chaos, the side lines, the undercurrents of despair, the clever surprises, but mainly it made me really properly laugh out loud quite a few times and I really enjoyed watching the story unfold until the bitter end.I bet the actors really enjoyed working with this intelligent and unusual piece of drama.

reviews.review_title: A wacky adventure where Dr. Who prints out illegal pornography on his home computer!
reviews.content: This is a great example of good actors carrying a bad story. David Tennant is great as he always is, but if you think too much about what's actually happening you realize it's actually really, really stupid...The whole time they keep repeating the phrase that good people can kill anyone under the right circumstances. So they give you David Tennant's character who is "The Vicar" as a set up to prove this point - subjecting him to a series of ridiculous coincidences that set him on a path to murder his son's math tutor.So, his creepy mentally ill co-worker (Edgar) just gives him a USB to hide it from his mom. He says it's porn so the vicar puts it in his pocket like "hey man, I got your back, your crazy religious mom wont find your porn, nbd." So he takes it home and accidentally puts it in a place where his son's math tutor uses it for some homework thing. She opens it up and she sees it's not regular porn it's CP - no one knows this but her at this point.His son walks in while she's looking at it, he doesn't see the screen but somehow knows it's porn - so he thinks the USB is filled with HIS materials, not CP, and he apologizes for her finding "his porn". So he appears to admit it's his and the tutor is like "ew, I'm leaving" and the Vicar tries to get her to stay and talk about it so she doesn't report his son to the police. He fights with her, accidentally pushes her down the stairs, and then locks her in his basement while he figures out what too do.This scenario is what "forces" a good person to kill an innocent person over a misunderstanding... Except the only way this situation was able to play out was by having Tenant's character forget a MAJOR bit of information HE brought up! After the lady is in his basement, he decides to coax and record Edgar confessing to owning to the CP. Tenant says "Don't lie to me, there are ways for people to find out this USB is yours" and this is true (forensics, duh)! So why didn't he just let the lady leave thinking what she wanted and give the USB to the police?Somehow in all this he is concerned that his work buddy - who is a predator - is a suicide risk and he doesn't want to put him in a bad state of mind... So what does he do? He TAKES THE BLAME for owning the CP - puts it on his own laptop and then prints them out on his home printer! 😂 Why?! There is no reason for any of these choices other than to prop up that the Vicar is a "good guy". Perhaps he's got some real affection for Edgar but we never see a good reason to defend a pedophile in their scenes together.All of this happens while Moffat tries to build another story to weave into this CP story and it's just so ridiculous. The journalist you follow throughout the story really only serves to weakly tie Stanly Tucci's genius criminal mystery solver character to the David Tenant storyline - it's a build up with no pay out.To add insult to injury, the direction and tone is totally bazar. They go from tearful scenes where they acknowledge the Vicar is going to prison and their family is ruined but 5 minutes later they have the Vicar's wife doing a little comedy bit where she's trying to defend herself with a kitchen knife and makes lightsaber noises. They insert this inappropriate comedy relief all over like it's Dr. Who like forcing a scene where David Tennant's character must do a birthday shout for a delivery guy's mom asking him to say "happy birthday from the sexy vicar".There is so much more to say, but this show stole hours of my life I can't get back.

I was definitely disappointed by this because Steven Moffat wrote it and David Tennant was the lead in this. Both are writers/actors that I greatly respect so it sucks that their work went into something as subpar as this. The story here is kind of boring. There are moments here and there but for 3/4 episodes, I was questioning why I had even put this show on other than my love for Moffat and Tennant. Most of the acting here is great. Tennant, as usual, gives a fantastic performance and Stanley Tucci and Lydia West were really great as well. The writing for some of the characters though especially Tennant is REALLY bad. Tennant's character is so stupid that it genuinely ruins the show. It ruins the show because his misunderstanding is the basis for the story of the show. Why on Earth would he accept a flash drive from a suspicious person that he knows regardless if he's a pastor or not and why on earth would he love the flash drive out in plain site when he knows that there is definitely something bad on there. Instead of explaining to the teacher how he got the flash drive, he instead tries to cover for his son and act like the flash drive was his. His character was just incredibly and unbelievably stupid and really ruined the show to the point where once we learn the fate of Tennant's character, I just don't care because he deserved it for being so stupid. Stanley Tucci's involvement was very boring. We only cut back every once in a while to him and for someone on death row, he has a VERY surprising number of contacts that he enlists to help Lydia West's character solve the case. I would probably recommend avoiding this even if you are a fan of Moffat or the actors.

Really?!! How I wanted to love this! I mean come on, David Tennant and Stanley Tucci should be a no-brainer that we are about to watch something superb. It's been stated by others: great cast, starts out as many such stories do, unfolding, twisting, turning-quite beautifully...but then, the story goes off the rails. Was the writer trying to be edgy or avante-garde? It's the kind of show that I'm either going to have to watch again 3 more times to finally get it, or I'm just going to walk away forever in disgust. The build up is great, the actors are sublime, but please! The last episode is terrible. What a shame!

I enjoyed the first half hour of the first episode. The prison setting with Stanley Tucci was chilling, clever & funny in equal measure. If only this had been the main storyline. David Tennant was as always great in his role. But the plotline involving discovery of what was on the memory stick was ridiculous. In no realistic scenario would anyone have acted in the way the characters responses were written. It was far too contrived & ridiculous for me to keep watching (as I could see things were only going to escalate from that point onwards). Less is sometimes more when it comes to storylines, and this one was just far too obvious.

Started out as a great concept and Moffat has a pretty terrific history. However this would have been much better boiled into 2 episodes or just written better... The show went from an interesting fantasy crime drama to completely convoluted and overall frustrating to watch. Rather than episode 4 being a climax full of tension and suspense, I had already mentally checked out and were just tiredly waiting for a resolution. Very promising at the beginning, but it didn't meet my expectations at the end. Stanley Tucci is fantastic, and his performance safes this show a bit. Overall the plot is very predictable and confusing at times. The ending didn't make any sense and it ended up
Disappointing.

Was the plot insane? Yes - but I watch so many shows that are endlessly predictable, even when the writer is convinced they have included enough curve balls to confuse and astound the viewer.This however was so utterly absurd that it kept me beguiled to the very end. I can't understand the rational behind a single decision the vicar made but that is what made it so insanely refreshing.I recommend you watch the show in its entirety and choose not to dwell on every bonkers decision that unfolds before you. I can honestly say I have never seen anything like it. A farce? Yes - but a very entertaining one.

Generally with Steven Moffat created shows he puts out a good couple of seasons and then the show gets terrible.Steven Moffat's writing for this show is some of the worst I've ever seen. (And I was excited when I saw he created the show and wrote it)Almost every plot point is not believable in the slightest.Seriously not one characters actions make sense.There is one thing that gets you to keep watching and that's the mystery around Stanley Tuccis characters wife which is never revealed and never will be because this garbage isn't getting a second season.It feels like this is the first draft of a freshman university students assignment written while walking to class to hand it in.

Oh God how can this be so bad...
Definitely the worst show i ever seen. Had to force me to the end in order to see if it could get any worse.Spoiler alert: It gets worse any minute that passes.Save yourself from this.Dont get me wrong, i only gave rating 1 because it's not possible to give 0.The story is far from being reasonable and the characters seem all dumb and without nonsense.The only positive point is the series only having 3 episodes and then you can end your suffer sooner.Please watch something else than this, but if you want to proceed i wish you the best luck for your mental health.

This is such a silly series. I watched the first episode, and it was so dumb it was not worth continuing. Sure, there is a person on death row that solves murders. OMG, talk about a stretch. While I like Stanley Tucci, this is a silly role to play but I guess as long as the checks do not bounce people will do it. No idea why some people like this, but then again, some people have no idea what a good movie or series is anymore with all the garbage on Netflix and other sources. If there was a word to describe this series I would opt for DUMB! If you like dumb shows, then this is right up your alley.

I loved this show until the scene where David Tennant unexplainably can't prevent that his USB stick is shared. He then weirdly can't explain why he has it and where he got it from. It's of course bizarre that he accepted it to begin with. But then start the SCUFFLE! Utterly without reason, he harasses the lady that's just trying to get out of the house. It's so beyond stupid that I immediately lost any and all interest for this show. It's a massive shame given Stanley's role, that he is fulfilling brilliantly. I guess I'll avoid all David Tennant movies from here onwards - just not my kind of actor.

reviews.review_title: A BIG WASTE OF MY TIME
reviews.content: I watched the complete series to the very end thinking it would be good because of the talented cast and because the first 10 minutes grabbed me. I should have stopped watching after the first episode because it all went totally downhill from there. This show was boring, extremely depressing, and really dark. Don't bother wasting your time watching this piece of garbage. The story and subject matter is horrible and there is absolutely nothing redeeming about it or it's atrocious characters. DID I FORGET TO MENTION THAT THIS SERIES WAS A TOTAL WASTE OF MY PRECIOUS TIME!??? Two Thumbs WAY, WAY down!!!!!

INSTANTLY hooked! I loved EVERY second of this series! I hope to see more of Atkins' character in the seasons to come, his sarcasm & wit is one of the books! I loved David as Doctor Who & enjoyed his character here as well. Let's not forget the great Stanley Tucci, AWESOME job, once again! My ONLY issue is crazy Janice. But how could she NOT be crazy with a name like that. Dolly Wells played her part extremely well. There HAS TO BE A SEASON TWO because Janice wants to kill her husband and I must admit that this tease of four episodes was a movie and I truly hope to see more of the vicar, Dillon, & Grieff.

reviews.review_title: Some key elements are far fetched
reviews.content: OK, one of the most important elements of the plot, THE most important element, the KEY ELEMENT, is kind of overboard and forced, - you just have to get over that. The rest is much more enjoyable if you can do that. I think in this short series they're trying to show how people can become unhinged and do things that they would NOT normally do. They think they are doing them for the right reasons, but actually they are totally wrong and selfish. They can not stop themselves. You sort of have to suspend your disbelief. After that it all plays out. You have to look at this series as a satire played way over the top, but in a stylish way. This 4-part mini series is played out very much in the old "everything gets resolved just in time and by good happenstance" and "all is well that ends well". But does it?? The tangled webs we weave do indeed catch us in the end.

I felt the need to put a counterweight to all the negative reviews on this wonderful mini series.Why does a piece of art/entertainment have to be 'believable'?Our imagination is one of the most wonderful aspects of being human.Agreed, it is a twisted plot, not everything is always clear, or explained in detail, one is left with questions, that are sometimes answered, sometimes not; but the dialoque, the acting, the suspense! So much to enjoy.Right from the start the code is clear; this is not a real-life drama/thriller, but instead an imaginative black comedy about morality, responsability, the human psyche in all its facets; sometimes things make sense, more often they don't. Just as in real life, I would say.

reviews.review_title: Plot holes all over the place but a darned good yarn
reviews.content: The weakest link was the script. Seriously, flash drives to hold the porn were a key component in the plot? In 2022?Total suspending disbelief for the behavior of the vicar. Surely to God (his god) he would protect the lives of innocent children over the life of his verger, the paedophile, without blinking an eye and go to the police, stat? As would have any decent caring human being.But no, much dangling threads ensued. Stanley Tucci gives an incredible performance but again, why is he allowed so many privileges in his cell and allowed to conduct mini-workshops on crime and solutions in prison? It's not revealed, but was the prison warden on some kind of payroll of his?It got a little keystone coppish with the vicar's wife plotting mayhem and murder and the journalist finding her, etc. Far too many useful coincidences to count. But hell, the performances were wonderful and I could see what the script writers were trying to do, some satire and spiritual songs thrown in and a little twist at the end.I gave it a 7, going against the grain here but the tension is kept up throughout and you have to wonder where it's all going.7/10 from me.

Is this what it has come to? So nonsensical that I'm writing this review. Two storylines, one bad and one terrible, linked by a fantastical narrative concocted surely by a child.I am ashamed of myself for sitting through it to the end. Yet, here we are. The bald guy in prison is relatively engaging. I am not sure if the journalist is supposed to have special needs, perhaps? The child and the teacher are somehow boring and infuriating. The wife getting knocked over by a truck is utterly pointless, and the rest watches like a ditched 'Emmerdale' pilot.Everyone involved should be sacked and given a 6 month ban from all television work.Overall, dreck.

I love Stanley Tucci and I found his portrayal brilliant. IMHO I personally think a lot of the negative reviewers are either missing the point or didn't past the first episode. I see a lot of low reviews complaining about plot holes and the story is not believable. Yet we highly rate shows and movies that have magic DNA that defies science, action heroes that always save the day, time travel, and even superheroes with powers and other magical being because they are believable? Walking Dead? Game of Thrones? This is TV, not a documentary. Some of the complaints seem a bit "nitpicky", to me at least.The rest contains spoilers so stop reading now if you need to.About the journalist protagonist, there is no proof she is ACTUALLY a published journalist other than her word. She could be green journalist, a blogger who fancies herself a journalist, or some weirdo obsessed with crime, so train scene could be explained.People are hung up on the drive, but Edgar was obviously not rational and suicidal, but he should think clearly? Does not seem unusual he would run to his vicar whom he seems to trust in his panic.As far as why the vicar made the odd decisions he did, we may assume there is some sort of confidentiality clause in play attached to his faith for anything Edgar told him. Even if his faith had special rules that exist for abuse, he made a snap decision to protect his family. Even if he did give up Edgar, it doesn't mean he would be believed.It does not seem completely unreasonable to assume he might panic in the moment. This IS a vicar that swears constantly, and is married to a wife who does not seem to really believe in God, and he took the drive in the first place knowing what it contains (at least partially). I am not defending his actions, but people always believe a man of God when it comes to accusations of abuse right?A cuddly sidekick murderer, a warden who seems on the side of right but makes a questionable moral decision that breaks a law or two. Panic, stupid decisions, contradictory characters, all of these are designed IMO to make you think about stereotypes, preconceived notions, and to ponder that any one person is capable of anything given the right circumstances.I personally believe the ending was intentional to setup for a second season. The core story was wrapped up, but no, not everything that was teased was revealed (we've heard of Lost right?). Did I want to know, sure, but I am not going to lose sleep over it if a second season never appears.This type of show is not for everyone, but I enjoyed it and recommended it for anyone capable of seeing it for what I believe it to be.

I've rarely been as disappointed by a show as much as by this one. So much so that I created an account just to warn people. Even if this show was supposed to be a spoof of some sort, it would insult anyone's intelligence. The premises are unbelievable, all characters are caricatural, and it needs we a long conversation scene at the end to explain all this nonsense. Prisoners on death row are allowed to come and go and receive visits as they're pleased. The "brain" of the show is an insufferable spoiled brat who speaks cryptically and thinks he's smarter than everyone, which he is de facto since everyone else acts as if they were on drugs. Don't waste your time.

reviews.review_title: Had the potential to be good, but it's really, really bad
reviews.content: Don't waste your time like I did.A Church Vicar is handed a USB drive full of child pornography by a suicidal colleague, the priests' sons maths tutor happens to load the USB drive into her laptop and views all of the indecent images.At this point (20 mins in) I thought this programmed couldn't get much worse. But just when I thought it couldn't get any worse, it did. A spiral of unrealistic and outrageous decisions are then made by the Vicar.To add insult to injury, another ridiculous storyline is weaved into the programme of two people on Death Row (in the UK, btw - where capital punishment has been outlawed for almost 60 years).I won't waste any more of your time reading this. Just don't watch it. It's really bad.

First episode, even the second to some extent, started with promise.However, I think it was supposed to be a comedy. The entire thing was so absolutely farcical on every level.The soundproof cellar. The convenient timing of everything. The stubbornness of the vicar. The laptop email being sent would have revealed the IP address and location etc. The twists aren't even good.It's just a very poorly thought out series all round.The actors in it are also for the most part just boring and lacking any depth.Random graphic deaths. People walking past fatal traffic accidents with blood everywhere as if they were an annoyance to their daily shop.All from a USB stick.

Only the excellent Stanley Tucci (and the homunculus (joke) cell mate geezer) saves it from zero stars. The story with the vicar (& his wife) doing what he was going to do is so far beyond ridiculous, it's ridonkulous. Both he and his wife were so unappealing as characters you can't even care about their supposed moral dilemmas, their anger, and various other emotions and, to be honest I don't know how to describe something further / worse than beyond stretching credibility? What's beyond the beyond if you see what I mean. Wherever that is, this is just a little bit further. I'm a bit scared that by the ending it appears they may be intending to make further mini series of this trash.

reviews.review_title: The rating of this show is a reflection on society
reviews.content: How is this not rated higher? I found it absolutely riveting and engaging. Maybe I'm the oddball who likes talking about things like ethics, morality, and justice. I found the vicar's situation to be incredibly complex and how he played it out (I'm only 2 episodes in so more to come) was incredibly...I'm at a loss for words. It was powerful. I'll say that. Who is innocent? Who is guilty? Who would be tried for what? How would God judge their actions. There's so much going on to contemplate. Story - great. Acting - great (hats off to the character and portrayal of Stanley Tucci's). Vicar and wife - great. This should be used as a case study (fictional as it may be) for ethics classes at the graduate degree level and above.Now...as I said - I'm 2 episodes in. Here's hoping it stays on course.

I really liked the first episode. The main character is awesome. However, the plot line with the vicar rests upon logic that no normal person would make. There are many places where the misunderstanding could have easily been reconciled. An added insult is scientific knowledge about CO gas toxicity is blatantly wrong; this should be known by most people. For a show this elaborate, one would think they would have hired a scientific consultant. Still entertaining, but I has problem maintaining even the moderate level of attention needed to follow the plot. The main character and the journalist carry this show.

I finished "Inside Man" mini-series released recently, so that you would not need to. No, really, don't waste your time on it even if you like David Tennant.The show tries very hard to seem smart, while almost any interaction between characters is utterly unnatural and stupid. And yes, I know, that "people are stupid", but not to this extent. They will not act like that under these circumstances.One would also think, that having an inmate acting as Sherlock Holmes is a good idea... But no. It's already a trope and it has been done much and much better before. Here's it is more like a bunch of cliches done with no feelings behind them.I was kind of forcing myself to finish it, hoping, that maybe in the end there will be an interesting twist... But alas. In fact, during 3rd episode I thought out a twist, that would have turned the whole story upside-down and properly connect, essentially, 2 separate stories. I was hoping that that would be the case, even though it was somewhat obvious, but no. Another opportunity lost to poor writing.The only good thing is that it kind of mentions the approach to support, that I preach: "assumptions are good only when you try to validate them". But that's not something most people will be interested in.

reviews.review_title: Disappointing doesn't begin to describe what could have been gripping and clever
reviews.content: Moffat, Tennant, Tucci, that was enough to get my attention. By the middle of episode three I was going to switch to something else, as it was too terrible to continue. As I dropped back to the menu I noticed there were only four episodes (I thought it was six and couldn't imagine sitting through that much more) so I figured I'd spend the extra 90 minutes to watch train wreck to its conclusion. Should have followed the principle of sunk cost but didn't. Anyway, for characters who are supposed to be so "bloody clever" I couldn't believe how bloody stupid their actions and dialogue were scripted. Even my own limited intelligence was insulted. The plot setup in episode one is so ludicrous I almost turned it off then. On the other hand, the performances and screen presence of the stars kept me hanging on in hopes of some revelation or twist to explain why these characters were so impossibly deplorable. I love Christopher Walken. That doesn't mean I'll ever watch Balls of Fury. I also love Tennant, Tucci and some of the great UK actors that appear in supporting roles. For style, performance, production and potential I gave it a generous six stars. There are worse things to watch. There are also far better.

So many "just go with it" contrivances in this lazy swing at a mediocre story can't be saved by the two great perimeters at its center.Death row inmates solving crimes, Vicars just casually handling information and then politely being interrupted by people accusing them - then going to extremes rather than address the criminal in the situation directly.This is just a weak set of details trying to be meaningful, so full of holes that even excellence can't keep it afloat.Research, editing, thesis, story - these are all very good things to include in a script. Even a stupid one like this.Just pass.

Absolutely amazing!I love the fact there is 2 lines of the story parallel to each other and actually it meets at a point.Truly incredible actors and actresses and the producer is phenomenal!So well written made me glued to the tv for the whole duration of the programme. I love the twists and how can someone turn to another person just purely because of one single reason!I just wish it was more episodes.I loved the depths of the characters the way how they coordinate to each other.People saying it is confusing well they didn't pay enough attention during the episodes as everything make sense and listen and watch the details!Fantastic! Congratulations!

A great premise with a disappointing end. I expected some more from this series. I mean in the end I was thinking of Janice as the villain for once because I was thinking that nobody actually saw what's in the pen drive and she might be bluffing and playing with their minds and that would have been brilliant. But still great acting by everyone and a good direction. I like the side stories a lot but some of the characters were left high and dry like Morag. I still have question on Edgar's intention on writing that letter or did his mother changed the letter? Because that letter became pivotal In the story.

reviews.review_title: 2 different show concept mashed into 1, with plot issues and unlikeable characters
reviews.content: This show feels like 2 different shows, an american procedurale, and a british crime drama, forced into 1.The american part of it, featuring Tucci's character as a death row inmate who solves crime, seems hopelessly underdeveloped and also does not seem to serve much purpose for the actual plotThe british part of it is the best part, but that still isn't saying much. Characters make the most unbelievable decisions, and ultimately the entire story would never happen because 1 single phone call to the police would have completely solved the entire plot.At the end we are supposed to be interested in the backstory of Janice fife for season 2, but she is so utterly unlikeable I can't imagine anyone being interested in seeing that.

This show is an absurd dark comedy morality play. Like a lot of Moffat's work, the parallels are being played out throughout. The set up seemed sophomoric, but the twists and escalations were so smart! The story is neatly packaged with a couple of ancillary surprises thrown in. The sneering opening dichotomy is the template for all of the stories that come after. Stanley Tucci as an evil ... genius... is a lovely touch. Some of my favorite small touches: the wife who tells the vicar upon leaving church with her husband - he's still an atheist. Bens girlfriend pointing out how strange it is that his parents are the vicar and the woman who $&@!s the vicar. I was absolutely delighted by this show. The show could have been better with more nuance, but in todays world, nuance is too often overlooked.

reviews.review_title: US story good; UK story utterly preposterous
reviews.content: And I say that as a Brit, so it's nothing to do with bias.Given the writer and the cast I had high hopes, but they were largely dashed. I must say that there were great acting performances throughout, but honestly: the UK half of the story was ludicrous almost from the outset, and I very nearly stopped watching during the first Holly Wells/David Tennant thumb drive scene, so aggravated was I by the way things escalated in such a totally unrealistic way.Then, almost every ridiculous decision made and every far-fetched event that transpired thereafter just added to my irritation; but I felt I had to see it through because it was certainly a compelling story despite the artifice.Long before the end, though, it had reached the point were I was almost shouting at the screen to tell them to stop doing such stupid things. (And without giving too much away: a certain important feature was supposed to be totally soundproof and impervious to harm - with a hammer, for instance - come what may?!)I know that it was all about panicked people doing irrational things and seeing events get rapidly out of hand, but there were far too many holes to allow me to suspend disbelief - and there was much that required suspension!The Stanley Tucci stuff, on the other hand: all very cool and classy. I only wish that could have been married to a far more believable companion story.Make sure you stay through the credits, though: there's a fun twist!

So bad, it could not even justify as a spoof. Completely unrealistic characters, situations and behaviours. The "funny" sidekick killer of 14 women was just desperate and in very poor taste. Very poor concept and execution. We watched the first episode shocked at how it made absolutely no sense at all, and then proceeded to give up having read other users' reviews, who had wasted the whole 4 hours on this hoping for some late sense to return. Sadly not. The actors worked hard with some appalling material and should have given up on this at script reading stage. I hope Moffatt's Brian hasn't completely imploded.

First of all, Mad respect to moffat, coupling is a fantastic masterpiece, and I just cant say anything bad about something moffat have touched , even this serie , inside man is in many ways very good , you grow into it pretty fast - the idea is good and the production is quality, not to menchen the acting, absolute fantasticIt start well - smart written and you cant stop watching it , but then it slowly turn in the wrong direction- start to be stupid and uncomfortable and suddenly its just not so good anymore , just when you think things start to be really intersesting it twist and got silly instead - and worst of all is the annoying reporter womanThought for a while Netflix had a good serie,,,

reviews.review_title: Awful. More holes than a teabag.
reviews.content:
I dont know why i watched episode two...it got to me shouting at the tv. Its absolutely ridiculous...RIDICULOUS. The vicar is a narcissistic lunatic, throwing his life away. The only reason ive given any stars is Stanley Tucci and his prson mate are fantastic.Daisys character comes across as the manipulator, the sons a wet dweeb, the wife just lets things happen and the vicar...makes you want to go to his massive house and lock him in a cupboard. Please tell the actor who plays the son to change his hairstyle...truly dreadful. The obvious just didnt happen...phone police get man arrested..
Simple. Instead its trying far too hard to be clever and fails abysmally.

reviews.review_title: Almost so bad it's good, almost.
reviews.content: It's bad, it's really bad, it's almost so bad it's good, but it isn't. 1 out of 10 is doing it a favour.The whole premise of the show beggars belief, people behaving in the most idiotic and damaging way to themselves and the people around them, at every turn I was expecting some sort of bizarre twist to justify what I was seeing but it never came it just built upon bad and unrealistic behaviour and situations over and over again.Sherlock was entertaining in its own way but it certainly isn't as good as people give it credit for, Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman made the show and papered over it's obvious cracks and its ever more, as the show went on, outlandish story telling, this cast as good as they are cannot save this mess that Moffat has created, created is probably the wrong word but anything more accurate would be insulting.A cast of superb actors wasted is the kindest thing I can say about this. Avoid at all costs unless you want to see acting talent wasted, this is quite literally an example of how not to write a crime drama. Somebody at the BBC needs to take a good hard look at themselves, this is the channel that gave us Edge of darkness, An ungentlemanly act, Tinker tailor soldier spy and Smiley's people way back in the 80's, to say they have fallen away is quite the understatement.Currently sitting at 6.4/10 here on Imdb, a score that as unbelievable as the show itself.

reviews.review_title: Great performance from Stanley overshadowed by absolutely ridiculous sub plot!
reviews.content: Such a shame the scenes with Stanley Tucci are actually pretty good and watchable but the show completely fails on the completely unbelievable story line with the Victor. Like seriously from 10 mins in call and ambulance, help the woman and explain the bind you were in trying to protect your congregation member. Victors wife going straight to let's murder her an hour after the incident. Seems likely character development! Not!I just fast forwarded all the vicar, math teacher and wife sciences and the rest wash ok.Stanley, his cell mate and reporter have good dynamic and script is good. Did 2 different people write this show and then some idiot just merged them together?!! Who knows!

Let's ignore the plot holes, let's ignore the daft willingness to murder, let's ignore the easy access visiting system for prisoners on death row. Actually, let's not! This is one of the most contrived wannabe clever plots I've seen in quite some time. Moffat can write some good stuff, like the blink episode of Doctor who, but let's be honest parts of sherlock were a bit liberal with the logic too. That such a mediocre thriller ended open ended was a bit too cocksure too, the assumption that it warranted a second series was a tad grating, and I for one will look forward to not watching the sequel. Hopefully no one will kill me for writing this negative review, although, according to the logic of this programme, anyone is capable of it.

reviews.review_title: Don Isidro Parodi would not be proud...
reviews.content: The first time I saw the trailer, I felt something was fishy.I didn't quite know what it was, it felt somewhat weird because I just knew there was something here that seemed way too familiar to a book I've read before. As I watched the first episode and Stanley Tucci's character starts solving crimes while in prison, it just hit me: This is 1942's Six Problems to Don Isidro Parodi by Borges and Casares!I mean, sure, they twist and twirl it a little (adding a subplot to divert the attention and pad the runtime) but that is basically the same notion overall.Look, it isn't bad at all, the acting is pretty solid (but come on, Tennant and Tucci, how could it go wrong?) and the story is, if not exactly going to blow anyone's mind it is decent enough to entertain for what it is. I just think Don Isidro solved this one first...

It's kind of show that you can't just finish and say "nah, not my type", as soon as you finish it, loud voice in your brain says "warn the nation, save them from watching this absurd hell of a show"We start with so popular cliche of someone related to church who's a pedo, but this ped* is not just a ped*, he's most stupid person on earth too. He decides to store his precious collection on USB stick... and because of fear of his mother. Then he hands it to vicar.......... Other than crushing it, hiding it in his shoe, his office, his books, his ass hole or billions of other logical places. There was just two stupid illogical options, one: to hands it to his mom, two: to hands it to vicar.. In church.., and our beloved writer decided to go with the second illogical option and he builds his castle of cards arounds it.The math teacher,WHY WOULD.

The first episode started good, until the whole scene with Janice and Harry this is the dumbest episode plot ever. All could have been avoided there is no way it needed to lead to what it lead to. The writing should have been better. The actors are good but for Harry to take the blame and not explain himself to get Janice to understand so she could make the decision is beyond's me. There is no excuse for Harry to have taken the blame for any of it. This whole scenario has frustrated me to no end. There is no good excuse one has or could give. This part of the plot needs to be done over because a normal person priest or not would not have done all that.

reviews.review_title: Almost a black comedy of errors.
reviews.content: When I say Inside Man was almost a black comedy of errors, I don't mean it as in a laugh aloud kind of way.It was just how one thing can set off a chain of events that turns into absolute chaos. You know - digger yourself deeper and deeper. Well that is exactly what happens in this brilliant series by Moffat.I don't even want to say the plot on here and give it all away. So no spoilers here.Tennant is fantastic as the Vicar. Being good certainly does him no favours, where ultimately if he would have done what was the utmost good and told the truth right from the start, the chain of disasters would not have ensued and I am sure justice would have eventually prevailed.This series is quirky, tongue in cheek, interesting and keeps you wondering what the next move will be.Definitely worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Acting talent, appalling script and story
reviews.content: Where to start! Okay if you are fans of any of the actors maybe watch this, if you like a really daft plot line with holes as big as canyons and because ( again) you like the actors watch it, if you enjoyed Stanley in that programme about Italian food then watch it.In retrospect the scenes in the jail with Stanley are odd ball and quite entertaining. The interchange between Stanley and his fellow inmate who acts as his human recorder are fairly amusing. I also liked the warden and Stanley's father in law ( the vicious criminal!)Other than this you really, really should avoid this nonsensical, vacuous codswallop!

reviews.review_title: Good concept but hate the production
reviews.content: This serial really had potential but if any producers would could take care of him it wouldn t been so much disaster. Worst acting of 2 characters i ve seen of my entire life. Bad lines and random characters from the movie just change everything like the son in 3rd episode. Not recomend it. Frustated me so much of that captive woman that i could kill her (obviously in the film) from the second episode. This could be a longer version too, where the case is coming back and he needs to defend himself or some action where he and his family moved out of their city and sisters captive woman try to kill them.

reviews.review_title: Had such potential... what a waste of great talent
reviews.content: The cinematography, actors and acting were fantastic but they can only do so much with a crap script.Too many "as if" moments for it to be believable. My husband and I watched to the end thinking it would get better. The last episode was definitely the best, but did not make up for the weak plot.The connections between the two sets of characters didn't link convincingly. The investigative work from the "death row detective" also was not convincing. His privileges unjustifiable.And there's a weird little bit after the credits roll, perhaps hinting at another season - already looks like it will be equally silly.Don't waste your time.

I had to abandon this 30 minutes into the first episode, and I do not give up on drama easily, especially British drama. However, the instigating incident that sets up the show is so completely and utterly ludicrous, it would be impossible to get geyond. The suspension of belief and credulity required would be equal to accepting that politicians always tell the truth. The greater puzzle is why Tennant and Tucci, two incredible talents, got past page ten of the script without sacking their agents for even sending it to them. I am genuinely shocked that nobody looked at the rushes (rough edits) of the instigating incident and say, 'folks, we need a rewrite. This is complete rubbish.'

This is an embarrassing waste of talent. In order for the story to work, the characters have to do the most ridiculously improbably things and ignore any opportunity they have to do something sensible and obvious.The story bends human behavior into a completely unrecognizable shape in order to create the illusion of drama and tension.Which is a shame, because the actors are all excellent, especially of course Tennant and Tucci, I can't imagine what would have convinced two such world class talents to accept a script this... stupid. That's the only word for it - it's a stupid script.Even the premise is solid - there's the seed of a great series in there, smothered in poor, lazy writing.

The Stanley Tucci character is an interesting angle and he is a covers the part well. The David Tennant storyline starts and stays silly, he acts it out well but that side of the story is too far fetched with so many holes in the plot it just falls into farce.Stanley Tucci keeps you engaged enough to get through the series but in the future they will need to add a more story build, the one is this series doesn't match up.The dialogue is snappy and the cast is good but in the quest to be quirky and different is to much against the weak writing, probably one episode too long, it's not worth 4 more 3 or 2.

reviews.review_title: Cheap Plot Tools Are Not The Same As Suspence
reviews.content: How do you take a cast like this and make such a horrible waste of time? Gah!There are moments of real genius, and they kept me watching. The humor was appreciated against the backdrop of gore, both insinuated and graphically shown.The rest is just an endless series of blatantly stupid decisions made by supposedly intelligent characters. This is not a story. It's a giant manipulation, and I resent it. I'm actually angry.If it had been a book, I'd have thrown it across the room. As it is, 4 hours of TV viewing I'll never get back, all I can do is warn others of the risks. It's not a nice way to spend a day.

This is the worst thing I've seen for a while. I could have stopped it at ep. 1 or 2, but I only checked the other episodes just because they were only 4 and I thought to to give it a chance and maybe have a more complete idea about this "gem". I was constantly like "oh, come on...". Plot super-sized holes, unbearable characters, unbearable ambience when trying to appear funny for misogynists and women-killers (note: not showing something funny with such characters, or showing them to try to joke, but really the intention of the series is to introduce us to some sick fun around them, especially the one having killed 14 women who is presented like a calm funny bear).Friendly advice. Keep away!

Hey remember on Three's Company when Jack would overhear a conversation between Chrissy and Janet and instead of having a 10-second conversation to clear it up, things spiral out of control and next thing you know Jack and Larry are dressed as women down at the Regal Beagle while Mr. Roper shakes his head? Hilarious right?? Well that exact same concept applies here except instead the result is a religious pastor downloading horrific images to his own laptop, ruining his family, and committing violent felonies against an innocent woman. Hilarious right??I didn't get this show. I hated it so much I created an account to write my first show review ever. There was SO MUCH potential that was just squandered on lazy writing and a total lack of research or even understanding of how human interactions work.The tutor was touted as being so intellectually superior to everyone and immediately started manipulating the couple which started off rather clever but then just nosedived into her handcuffing herself and cracking her own skull. I kept waiting for some sort of payoff from her insane actions. I started to wonder if maybe the tutor was some masochist who enjoyed hurting herself.The "mysteries" Tucci solves are ridiculously laughable. (Also, people who plead guilty generally don't get the death penalty but now I'm just nitpicking.)I could go on but I'll stop and tell you to do yourself a favor and watch Three's Company instead.Two stars for the acting and directing which were actually pretty good and the scenery. I enjoyed the juxtaposition between the UK village and the American desert west.

It's hard to know where to start but why would a journalist take it upon herself to travel from the UK to the US to interview a killer on death row at her own expense when she doesn't even have a buyer for the article?! She then leaves after five minutes, defeated. This is after paying for a flight, a hotel and a rental car.When she was ringing Janice's landline after texting her mobile, one wonders how stupid the writers think we are. I seriously doubt that this practical stranger would give this person she just met on the train her full name, mobile AND landline, especially when Janice was adamant that she wouldn't be meeting Beth for the coffee.Plus the crimes poor Stanley Tucci supposedly solves, absolutely ridiculous, incredulous scenarios.As for the whole USB stick setup, give me patience.*rolls eyes*

Had a hard time with this series. The section involving the Vicker was too painful to watch. It was full of scenes where if this character did this or did that, that part of the plot would have quickly resolved itself.
