It's plot line required viewers turn off the part of their brains where common sense lives. Ended up fast forwarding through most of this story plot. I found the part involving Jefferson (Stanley Tucci) the saving grace of the series. The character was well acted and interesting as he talked out his theories. If there is a second season I hopes it's focus on him with a stronger backstory. Good acting, but it needed better writing.

reviews.review_title: The glaringly obvious plot hole just ruins it
reviews.content: Tucci and the American story line, just great, as you'd expect from this great actor. A Sherlock Holmes on death row storyline. The rest is just ridiculous and destroys the whole thing.As so many reviewers have said already. If the Vicar just told the truth (Which a)He should have and why wouldn't he and b) In reality you have nothing to hide and therefore the truth is obvious.)) Then the story is over and it's because of this massive blunder by the writers that destroys the whole premise. The lie is the most ridiculous aspect of the whole story. It would never have happened. With this in mind you can't help but thinking the whole series is a waste of time. You'll never get past the plot hole.Watch for the American story but skip the UK side, it doesn't work and is an absolute failure because of the glaringly obvious.In fact just skip the whole thing.

reviews.review_title: It isn't bad but just not what you thought it would be!
reviews.content: I had a slow start to getting into this series. I love the actors and looked for it to be a suspenseful who-done-it. Buuuut...it was not exactly that! It takes about the third & fourth episodes to see where this seemingly nonsense is going. It's not really nonsense but you have to not overthink the story & keep an eye on the connections to all the characters. It is really a morality tell, with a touch of Shakespearean tragedy. You have to get pass your expectation of a popularized true crime series we have come to expect. Only thing I still wish there had been more character development to really care about the characters, but in the end there is room left to get that too with this series.

I really didn't expect anything from this movie. Just thought it could be interesting since I am fascinated about prison movies. It was mostly happen outside the prison and it got me hooked almost from start. Forget about the plotholes and just enjoy the ride. One of the sickest plot in a long time. And a dark humour that I like. Entertaining and nailbiting at the same time. The story is about the prisoneer who was charged for murder who helps people investigate cases he found interesting, since he used to be a former detective. And there is the priest outside who puts himself in an absolute dilemma. Their paths are crossed while a young reporter investigates her friends disappearing. I so enjoyed this movie.

Honestly, I couldn't even make it past five minutes.The dialogue is terrible, extremely unrealistic. The idea that not a single person would even look at something bad happening on the Tube, let alone react just screams: "I've never actually used any form of public transport".And then all the women on the train suddenly saying "me too"... about 5 years after that train left the station.I just cringed through the whole first five minutes. I thought maybe I was crazy or had turned on the wrong show. Stephen Moffat project with Tucci and Tenant? And this is the opening scene. The thing that's meant to set the tone and hook you? Yeah, big pass from me!

It is important for me to put a disclaimer that writing a show based on a supposed probability of someone placed in a position of being accused a p/do while not being a p/dophile and, instead, desperately trying to prove otherwise and falling into only more trouble of being viewed as a p/do is not possible. Not only not possible, but destructive to the views we form on immensely important social issues. There is also a lot of questionable p/do-apologism and compassion, which certainly makes you question Steven's priorities in this life.Moffat tried to introduce a turmoil of insane events based on simple misunderstandings. It's an interesting premise and I very much enjoy characters that slowly lose it completely. However, Steven was not able to do anything with his material. The subject is all over the place. The Vicar and death row plot is not connected and the desperate attempts of trying to intertwine the two only weaken the plot and frustrate the viewer. The death row plot and Stanley's character should have been omitted entirely. It is irrelevant, it provides nothing but clever integrations of clever monologues to present in a clever light the clever Writer itself.Another huge issue of the show is Steven's desperation in trying to prove that he is not a misogynist. The female characters are horrible, you can sense Steven's anger with them yet the unique desire to prove to everyone that he actually loves and respects women. I wish someone would finally tell the guy that the weird fixation on non-misogyny actually makes him more misogynous. It would save us all trouble and finally set his mind at ease if we'd finally move away from this subject.Moffat also wants to teach its viewer a very pretentious lesson. "Everyone's a murderer" It is another one of those things Moffat writes as if his characters are saying something immensely intelligent. One second of thought and you can fully counterargue the completely bizarre and incomprehensible statement. It's crazy that the show actually ends with a full-blown monologue on this matter. There is a very specific line there, "Everyone is a murder on a bad day". Not really? Hello? I don't know Steven, if these are the type of thoughts that occur to you on your bad days, I strongly recommend therapy.It's also clear that the lesson of putting his characters "down", showing they aren't so moral themselves is Moffat's personal projection. You see, the viewers who consistently point out issues in Steven's writing or personal views are no saints themselves and should therefore stop judging him.Steven's problem is that he lost his track. He focused the mistakes pointed out and obsessed over them to the point of making each episode of late Doctor Who and Sherlock, Dracula, and Inside Man all about them. He fails to write female characters, he's too narcissistic, and inserts the idealistic self as a protagonist in each project made. However, he is still a great writer. And sometimes, when he breaks out of that self-centered cycle, his stories become exceptional. Unfortunately, I feel that Moffat has fully lost himself in that desperation of proving to be higher than the criticisms made, or being angry at them, or cursing the viewer for how they don't differ from his also. Each project is like a diary of jumbled frustrations that he just pushes out into the world instead of reflecting on how to overcome these feelings and writing something he actually likes.I tell you what, I think the plot could have been interesting. If removing the death row and journalist plot entirely and instead focusing on a closed-off environment of one family slowly losing themselves and fixating on what to do with a trapped woman in a cellar, it could have worked. You could understand the characters, why they do what they do, and how warped their realities are to justify their actions. It would make it an actual quality dark drama Steven obviously hoped to do. Alas, what we got is another Moffat hysteria instead of evolving his mastery and focusing on producing new, interesting, and innovative subjects.However, the casting is great. All great stars of British television and all a joy to observe. Although, I do hold some grudge that David agreed to participate in this. Oh well.2/10 for the beloved cast.

... I found the amount of silly choices made in the David Tennant side of the plot so annoying. The lack of communication and poor choices of every character were frustrating after a while and I just started fast forwarding through those parts to get to the parts with Stanley Tucci. He's always wonderful and continues to be in this. It's not a bad show, it's just also not the best. Great theme song though!It's a ridiculous concept but that doesn't bother me. I don't approach entertainment needing it to be entirely factual. I just find it's lazy to make it so poor communication and lack of common sense drive the plot.

reviews.review_title: I don't usually post reviews but...
reviews.content: The stars I gave were for the cast. Wonderful actors, terrible plot with SO many holes. From the start, someone else's memory stick tossed into the family key bowl and then you toss the maths teacher into the basement, WHO proceeds to dismantle and/or HIDE all the tools instead of working to find a way out? How about sawing the door during the night or breaking one of the basement windows? And sorry, just tell her to stop talking, from the start. Don't memory sticks have IP address links that would prove it didn't come from him or his son? This had the chance to be something, but it's just so ridiculously unbelievable. I do feel guilty saying that, as I want to be loyal to the actors I adore.

reviews.review_title: A jumbled story that could of and should have been better
reviews.content: Two great actors couldn't save this confused, murky but sometimes witty drama. The plot is based on a complete misunderstanding which could have been easily avoided. The subsequent actions from some of the protagonists were totally ridiculous.So the rest of the show struggles as it is based on a frankly ludicrous premise which renders it entirely unbelievable.There are two stories going on which are poles apart to begin but do come together in a reasonably satisfying conclusion.The young detective seemed miscast or produced a poor performance. I could go on as there was a lot wrong with this show.Despite that, you still find yourself wanting to know what happens at the end which is at least a positive.

reviews.review_title: There was a time when the BBC produced good dramas - but not now
reviews.content: The trouble with these four-part dramas is that when you start watching them, you want to know how they finish. It was such a waste of good acting talent i was hoping for a similar conclusion to The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas. The script is so unbelievable it was a waste of four hours of of prime time television.Stanley Tucci was in my opinion the only actor to come out of this rubbish with any credit - and he is on death row!If it was on ITV, at least I could have got some entertainment from the adverts.As for the fire in the cellar - why didn't Ben extinguish the fireAt least the accident was well staged.

reviews.review_title: Plot is so disjointed, it's a waste
reviews.content: Could be great, but wastes too much time with plot elements that don't connect up. It is a shame because the actors, cinematic and scenery could have been so much more and were billed as more. It really Needs a re-write big time to present the elements in a more connected way. Rule number one is don't waste the audiences time, but instead it wastes it time and again. Why anyone would write and present this way and think it is going to fly with an audience is beyond me. I tried giving it a chance several times and it still doesn't provide anything the audience would find rewarding,it just leaves you want it to work but it never does.

reviews.review_title: From bad to worse, literally and figuratively!
reviews.content: I wish I could give this ZERO stars, but that's not an option. Unfortunately. I will watch anything with David Tenent in it, so I did. What a mistake! Just shows you that even the best actors can make bad choices. Stanley Tucci is another great actor that usually makes everything he is in better. Not this time. If those two can't make this show any better, no one can! Imagine if those two weren't in it? I didn't think this show could be any worse but it occurs to me that maybe it could...if two other actors were cast in those roles. It's strains credulity but that's in keeping with this preposterous mess of a miniseries. What a ludicrous waste of talent, time and money. Just dreadful. Zero stars.

If a concept can be too brilliant, "Inside Man" illustrates that enviable problem. I don't like the series' creators and avoided it until a day when I said, How wrong can you go with David Tennant and Stanley Tucci?The spiritual torture Vicar Harry (Tennant) goes through reminded me of the trials Will Ferrell's "Marty" endures in Apple's "The Shrink Next Door." It's hard to portray real, grinding, incessant, unending spiritual torment in a way that will keep viewers' attention and interest. Most people exposed to matter this dark, whatever their religious faith if any, will call religious dark matter crazy or senseless, dumb or worse. "Inside Man" is from the first minute to the closing credits (literally) about a Dark Night of the Soul. The Night ends very happily for one person and very badly for others.Unlike "The Shrink Next Door," the spiritual darkness is offset by comic relief in the guise of a fetching young lass (Lydia West) who does the bidding of death-row inmate in the manner of Sherlock Holmes. Jefferson Grieff's (Tucci) execution-scheduling is part of the plot. For once, Dylan Baker gets a reprieve from playing smarmy Uriah Heep knock-offs and does a fantastic job as Tucci's compassionate prison warden. Atkins Estimond (Dillon) as a Watson to Tucci's Holmes is respected as a comic Dahmer-type. This part of the story takes place in the arid American desert.But the British part of the story is so relentlessly painful, it's inevitable certain viewers will recast it in ways that allow them to disdain it. Anyone who says the producers can't write female characters are mistaken. Dolly Wells as Janice Fife and Lyndsey Marshal as Mary, Vicar Harry's wife, are magnificent. Marshal especially is terrifying as a suburban wife and mother who segues in and out of being her own evil twin. (Tennant does this kind of thing so well, it's kind of not surprising that he's brilliant as a tortured soul. It's his schtick.)Just as "The Shrink Next Door" gives the viewer the unpleasant opportunity to sit through grueling amounts of spiritual pain--to teach lessons few Americans get drummed into them during religious services--"Inside Man" gives the viewer the even more unpleasant opportunity to sit through the ordeal of a woman trapped by utter coincidence in the hands of sane people situationally compromised. Marty triumphs in "The Shrink Next Door" at the cost of his entire life. Harry triumphs in "Inside Man" at the cost of his.I didn't even make popcorn. I sat through four episodes straight. Jefferson's (Tucci's) observation that all required to make a murderer is a bad day and bad timing... Ten stars.

This is an interesting but totally failed experiment in taking the kind of stupid and unlikely things that characters in broad farce do, but as a thriller. Without the payoff of humour, when characters react to a situation in a way that makes no sense whatsoever, over and over again, it's just grindingly and painfully annoying. It's like a strange lovechild of Coupling, and some Sherlock b-stories - both written by Moffat so perhaps that's not far off the truth. The acting is fine, the dialogue is fine. Everything, apart from the believeability of 99% everything that nearly all of the characters do, is fine.

None of this show makes sense - least of all why Tucci and Tennant ever agreed to this badly written drivel. Moffat tries to do a Sherlock-type mystery/reveal with the "genius prisoner on death row" angle, although his character is NOT AT ALL relevant to the show in any way. Back in England, the vicar and his family behave so wierdly that it leaves the viewer saying "well this escalated quickly". Why the bad people are bad, why the good people are so stupid, why the additional characters are even there at all and why oh why is it written so poorly are just a few other questions that you're left with.

Genuinely baffled by the idiocy of this show. Lydia West's character is completely unbelievable as a hot shot journalist. In episode 3 she asks death row murderer Stanley tucci why she hasn't gone to the police instead of ask him to help her friend who she suspects is currently in grave danger on the other side of the Atlantic... When Steven Moffat wrote that line, I'm bemused as to how he wouldn't have stopped to see that the entire plot of his show was... terrible. The script is laughable and the characters constantly say things that you wouldn't hear in real life, nor an irreverent Yorgos Lanthimos production.Both Dolly Wells and Lyndsey Marshal's characters are almost unwatchable. I've also never seen David Tennant so unsure of himself.The only resolve for this madness would be if it was intentionally a madness. But the hysteria nor the tone go nearly far enough to justify a wild knees up. Baffled.

reviews.review_title: I guess I am too smart for this?
reviews.content:
Stupid people making one insane decision after another, that are so utterly ridiculous, it hurt my brain.I sincerely hope people, who are not on drugs or mentally ill, would not really behave that stupidly. It is not a good thing, when your whole story hinges on such a whimsical premise, as is presented here.The somewhat good:
The Grieff part of the story is mildly entertaining at times. I liked Stanley Tucci, although his character was very unbelievable and Tennant was quite OK.Sadly, that's it with the positives.The main problem with the series is, that almost everyone acts absolutely idiotic. Maybe this is supposed to be a contrast to the allegedly brilliant Grieff. And I mean allegedly, because the solutions to the puzzles he solves are extremely contrived.The first problem he solves in about 10 seconds. When they revealed what the solution was supposed to be, I could only shake my head. It is like one of the old riddles, that you solve at parties with a group of friends. Only in the games you know, that those things are not meant to be taken seriously. Almost every episode of the Mentalist had better mystery at its core and this show ran for seven seasonsThe character of the wife was so bad I already forgot her name and regarding Jannice, bland is the only adjective that comes to mind. The moment they reveal she is supposed to be "smart" I snorted with laughter. You know, they tell you, so it must be true, even though all her actions up to that point were just idiotic. The rest of the cast are just forgettable set pieces. Beth the reporter is only there to propel the dumb story and don't even get me started on the utterly ridiculous metro scene with her. Ben, the son, is there for some scenes. That's it. He is a plot device for his father to try and "rescue". Once he gets some scenes with actions and dialogue, he of course acts as dumb as all the others. At least his character has the excuse of being a clueless teenager. On the other hand, we are told, that he is just lazy but quite smart ... yeah, sure he is. Actions speak louder than words, screenwriters.Then there is the main storyline, that revolves around the vicar and his family. I think this is by far the worst part of the series. At some point, I started forwarding the scenes, because they were just unbearably stupid. Dumb dialogue, stupid decisions with zero possibility to connect or sympathize with the characters or develop an understanding for their actions. They act too bizarre, too damn ridiculous to allow for that.So, there you have it. Some people seem to like it and I think this is mostly due to the attempts at humour. I'll grant that I smirked a few times and that, other than my positive points from the beginning, is why I rate this 4/10 and not lower.

With its woke, know-it-all main characters, this series perfectly encapsulates the zeitgeist of the last couple of years. Their willingness to 'help others' is clearly not so much out of empathy as it is to feed their narcissism.Without the abundant inconsistencies and implausibilities, the plot would not be able to accommodate the overly woke, pretentious characters in effortly knitting their way to a resolution. However, it does so quite well.On a side note.I'm pretty sure it's inadvisable to use that type of gas oven in a closed, unventilated room. Defect or no defect. So that's one thing the got right...

Excellent actors wasted in a stupid series. I kept thinking and hoping there would be something that made sense about the death row inmate and the vicar.The fact that the vicar was going to throw his whole life away for a troubled guy, not realistic! In fact, the whole story seemed unrealistic! And pointless!! I should have turned it off after episode 2!! But I kept thinking what if it gets better?? And it did not!!All I can say is it was a complete waste of time! I would not recommend it to anyone!! Which again, is too bad because the two main actor are usually in great movies and series! But, this one was a total bust.

reviews.review_title: how to create a killer through panic and love
reviews.content: I'm not a watcher of the Doc so I don't know the clever genius of this Steve Moffat but this show is an insult to storytelling. I just finished episode 2--every character has the worst instincts and neglects common sense, every new beat compounds the absurdities.A metaphor for this show would liken to: Stanley Tucci's character, Jefferson Grieff, having the answers to every thing, still drags EVERYONE in this slow-paced solve your own fools' mystery adventures-just for his own amusement--that's what Moffat's hubris is doing with our time! He's prepared 'clever' answers with mixed-bag wit, using an implausible plot, poorly executed twists at a penguin's pace (waddle waddle wad), and an irrational macguffin to anyone with a basic understanding of REAL-LIFE.What B-plot? Relevance? Convolute further. Dolly Well's character, Janice Fife, is just bloody suicidal, assumes the worst of the world, digging out accusations and doubts and manipulation-every opportune for a deeper grave. Who will it be? What's the opposite of pathos? Fife. Should've killed her outright and we would've gotten 'how to vicar away with murder.' Better show. Just go to the police with her, get interviewed, her side, then a VICAR presents relevant information like suspect acting strange, evidence, probable cause to search the lodging, solved.

I don't think this series is stupid nonsense or dreadful at all. I am not aware of any plot holes. It interested me to see how the plot involving Jefferson Grieff on Death Row in the US and the one with the vicar in Britain trying to protect both his son and his verger would be connected. I loved how it illustrated that anyone can become a murderer on a bad day. Obviously Grieff is the "inside man," but turns out that the vicar becomes an inside man as well. Great suspense and great acting. David Tennant and Stanley Tucci are great in every piece I've seen them in. Lyndsey Marshall and Dolly Wells are excellent as well. I think the series is very well made. I hope there will be another season.

I find it really difficult to define exactly what this is. Two parts of a story that link very tenuously and in a contrived way that ultimately disappoints.The issue for me is that the two strands are so different in time and quality that it is almost like watching two separate series with different writers and directors.In one strand we have Stanley Tucci as a death row prisoner who provides advice on criminal cases from his cell. This part is very good. Tucci is just the right level of sinister, and manipulative. He gets drawn in to advising on what is transpiring in the second strand of the story. It's how her gets involved that is contrived. This could have been overlooked if the second strand was any good. Overall I would rate that Tucci half of the story as 4 out of 5 stars.The problems arise in the other element of the story with David Tennant as the vicar. The story begins with him greeting his parishioners after his Sunday Service. After that nothing in this part of the story is remotely believable. The acting ranges from poor to downright surreal. I began to question whether it was supposed to be a dark comedy. It is t it is just awful in every way. The story, the dialogue, the acting. Even Tennant can't rescue this from the wreckage. As each episode comes around it gets more unbelievable yet entirely predictable. I give this part 1 out of 5 stars. I am being generous only because episode 4 gave me me a couple of good unintentional belly laughs.This could have been great. It isn't.

One of the reasons why I'm even bothered to be writing this review is purely because of the bad one's I've just finished reading.Yes the first 10 minutes of the show was rather cringe and made me second guess my decision on watching any further. But boy am I happy I did. It was totally worth the 4 hour binge and SPECIALLY the last episode, which had my jaw permanently DROPPED for 57 minutes. The last 3 probably more.There was just so many confusing yet exciting things happening all through and it made it even better that they threw some jokes in there. We all love a little dark comedy am i write?

But it does not: it continues with the same tonic until the end.

It started off promising-great cast and interesting opening scene. However, that lasted 15 minutes before it all fell apart. The entire plot stems from a dumb decision and unwillingness to listen. A simple explanation at the police station and getting the person help would have resolved everything. The entire series relies on taking the stupid baton felt like a waste of time.No characters is properly presented, everyone jumps to conclusions and a huge misunderstanding just makes this series very cringy.

I love good dramas and thrillers, however although it's sometimes necessary to 'suspend your disbelief' with some of them, the plot still needs to be fairly plausible. This show was not. Nothing that was done on this side of the Atlantic was believable. The characters were awful, I was wanting them to bump off the woman in the celler because she came across so awful. I'm no forensic expert but why would you try to kill yourself with carbon monoxide with a portable gas fire in a massive mansion like vicarage, cause it mite not work. Why would a vicar keep the secret of someone who was doing harm? And then pretend he was the one doing the harm? Why were they all using memory sticks ? Why was stanley tuccis timing so perfect. Why didn't they just make the American side; sadistic murderer solves a new crime every week.For a show to be enjoyable, the characters need to be likable and believable. These weren't.

I have just started and was excited to begin watching, but after a rather witty opening with Stanley Tucci, the ensuing journo and then David Tennant entry falls into farce immediately. None of these people are acting the way real people would. The dialogue is ridiculous. The character actions are slapstick, as written by a 12 year old. It had better ramp up in the logical action stakes if it's going to hold my attention. Or prove to be a surrealist masterpiece, which it's looking more like at the moment. Crossing fingers I can get through this episode with some clarity and discover something even vaguely believable.

reviews.content: Tucci is great. The rest is AWFUL Makes you scream on the show because it's so utterly ridiculous. Felt like it had promise , parts are interesting. But it's a wanna be silence of the lambs with weirder sex issues. Well shot, well acted, but the story is totally ridiculous. No one would ever act like this on the situation. Now would a prison allow a murder cart Blanche access to visitors, accelerates phone, and a " stenographer " with a photographic graphic memory who's also a psychopathic serial killer.. oh but he's "likeable" - so stupid it sounds worse typing. I rarely right reviews but this was offensively stupid.

The script reads like leftovers from the BBC Sherlock series. Must have been tough not to be able to make further series when they still had ideas.The inside man is a 'high functioning sociopath' solving crimes, this time on death row. Having a convicted murder solving crimes brings to mind a comment in the first series of Sherlock where a police officer says, "One day, we'll be standing around a body, and Sherlock Holmes will be the one that put it there."
If it wasn't for the complete improbability of the actions of certain characters, I'm looking at you, Sexy Vicar, then it's an entertaining, seat of your pants thriller. reviews.review_title: This is just what we needed
reviews.content: I can't believe how many negative reviews there are. This series has a great cast, it adds humor when you think it is going to be all serious and draws you in instantly The humor is there to remind you that this is a story, not reality. Just watch it and enjoy it. I mean, I guess it actually touches on how people think that, because they are religious, they are righteous.... Ohhhh....now I get the negative reviews.So, if you aren't a righteous religious humorless person, you will probably love it.I went into this knowing I loved the cast and storyline. It wasn't until I started watching that I was able to see the other meanings behind it. Parents who will go way beyond the realm of reality for their kids and in the most unhealthy way and how that way of living works out for everyone.

reviews.review_title: Great cast but a terrible let down
reviews.content: I was really hoping to like this show. How could you not with a cast of heavyweights like David Tennant and Stanley Tucci?Unfortunately, the big names are all the show has going for it. I rated it 5 stars because the actors were great in their own regards as actors. However the writing is sorely disappointing.Episode 1 starts off with an unbelievable storyline, forcing us to really stretch our imaginations and believe the sequence of events that are central to the show.Secondly, Tucci's character is loosely based on Sherlock Holmes but does not even come close to the mystery and excitement of Doyle's work. The deductions sound corny and over the top!Yes, I didn't watch past the first episode but I can't imagine the plot getting any better given my experience so far.

reviews.review_title: If plot holes drive you mad - don't bother!
reviews.content: Nobody would make the bizarre decisions that Neil Tennant's character does! It's all too silly! What of waste of a talented cast. Had to turn it off half way through episode 2. Couldn't watch anymore. It's a shame as it had such promise. Unbelievable plot.I genuinely can't believe that Stanley Tucci would sign up to something that is so ridiculous. Surely, when he read the whole script he would've been saying, 'Nope! That would never happen! No one in any state of mind would act like that.'I'm intrigued to know how it ends, but can't stand to watch it any further. It's just too incredulous to watch.

I watched the whole series because the concept was interesting, and I kept hoping it would get better. This show is American to the core. No character development, full of plot holes and unrealistic situations.First of all, the characters are very one dimensional and likable. The "inside man" is some sort of clairvoyant murderer, whom everyone likes and has many criminal contacts (even though he apparently didn't live a life of crime before murdering his wife. He claims that everyone is a murderer to be, and yet, he also thinks that murderers should be killed...The atonement (a word frequently used in the show - well done with the big word) are the actors. They are clearly talented.

reviews.review_title: Certainly surprised by the mixed rating!
reviews.content: Not sure why the reception is what it is for this series, I thought it was fantastic! They kept a small close knit set of characters and wove a story that kept me engaged the whole way through. It's especially interesting the whole concept that anyone can be a murderer...it just takes a certain set of circumstances for it to be true.Anything with David Tennant he blows out of the water naturally, really enjoyed watching him here again and you can really see his range from loving father to....what he becomes. As always this is another story that hinges on a family...and the story goes to some dark places.I could see some not believing how he acted, but one has to put yourself in the mindset of someone actually going through instead of a watchers lens. Nothing felt too out of place or so far fetched.Overall Inside Man is a great example of a tight story, executed well in a short amount of time. I think I much prefer this format compared to longer or ongoing shows!!

I never watch a crime drama that the brilliant detective didn't help with the case at all, and he almost let the victim got killed just because his arrogant.From Jefferson Grieff's so called theory, the victim Janice was either being kidnapped in her own house, or being kidnapped in her last appearance - the vicar's house.Then, what did he do?He called his father-in-law, just wasting time and showing off for asking the so called powerful father-in-law to send a team to rescue Janice, by misleading him that he kept his daughter's head there.On the other hand, he asked Beth to go to Janice's home. She got so lucky just because the vicar's wife Mary was stupid enough and want to put the notebook back to Janice's home. Otherwise Beth will also have no contribution for the case.And the ending is:
1) so happen the wife Mary "brought" Beth to the vicar's house,
2) so that Beth could stop the vicar to kill Janice just on time.3) And then the Father-in-law's team come and stop the vicar to kill Beth.So the question is: what did Jefferson Grieff contribute to the case except showing off and pretending smart?If he told Beth to go to vicar's home directly, problem solved. And actually she may stop the son Ben for attempting murder.If he think its too danger to ask Beth to go to vicar's home, then what's the point to ask her to go to Janice's home as there are also 50% chance Janice is being kidnapped there, by his own theory.Btw, what kind of vicar will murder an innocent teacher for protecting a teenager (Ed) who like to hurt children? And did he know that being a murderer's son could also destroy Ben's life?

What most of the reviewers on here aren't getting is that this is a farce. Brilliant acting, comedic timing and some really clever plot twists. I didn't have a clue what was coming next and how the two male protagonists could be linked. Credit to Moffat for pulling it all together with so much suspense, which meant I had to binge the whole season in one sitting. But it's most definitely a farce, don't treat it as a serious drama and you'll love it - probably. A couple of frustrating loose ends to tie up (hence the 8 stars), but that will make for a Season 2 hopefully. Definitely worth a watch...

A 3rd of the stars for Stanley's storyline, but the other 2/3rds of the totally implausible storyline handed to David Tennant et al, is a complete waste of talent.The nonsense fact of the circumstances that he finds himself in, covering for the verger, which is regardless of what his actions will do to his career, & more importantly, his family.And don't get me started on the usual stupid telly 'cops'.As for the psycho in the cellar...And then the writer puts the son in the cellar.And there's so many plot holes.It's almost like this series has been written by two separate writers. One good in the USA, and one crap one in the UK.

This whole story would simply never happen, all the vicar needed to do was boot Janice out of the house.The vicar had already regained possession of the memory stick and could have easily just destroyed it (pop it in the microwave or fire would do the trick). It would have then just been wild accusations by a math's tutor against a juvenile and his father the vicar, where there was absolutely no evidence to support her claims.It beggars belief that events could even transpire as laid out in this story.I love Tucci and Tennant but even they could not save this series. Again, disappointing especially as I also generally like Moffat's stuff.

Almost gave up as I am not a fan of vicars in general but kept watching.I realise it may not make sense to everyone but that is neither here nor there. It is TV people. A story. A darkish sense of humour helps and not taking everything so seriously. Some twists and turns and the actors are great. I certainly enjoyed Tucci's character.I am looking forward to a second season. Moffat is a great writer and one who I look for ever since finding him on Dr who. His stories are always entertaining and not the usual spoon fed nonsense so many seem to enjoy.They have hinted at things to be explained later. Why did Grieff have to bury her head? What was wrong with it? Will he delay his appointment? Will he tell the Vicar what happened and why?

reviews.review_title: The Bad Reviews Do Not Get This AT ALL
reviews.content: People are so used to be spoon fed by stupid and dumb TV series that when once in a while some thing clever comes up like this they completely miss the point and spend more time writing their broken ideas than trying to get whats going on. Tennant and Tucci are brilliant and so was the dialogue. It's a dark (and clever) series about the True nature of Man, his stereotypes, belief systems and that he knows nothing about any of these things. The storyline is not linear not logical but I thought that made it more interesting. A vicar who tries to take all the guilt just to keep others safe (anyone you might know maybe?), a vicars wife who calls the resurrection a fairy tale, a woman kept underground (Hades?) victim who 'devilishly' plays People against eachother, loveable murderers and a prison warden, an old man who is desperately looking for the body parts of his daughter pictured as a dispicable criminal?? And most daringly the analytic Mind of Holmes and Dr Watson on the wrong side of the Atlantic. Absolutely brilliant piece of work. Well done.

The premise of the series was good: a man on death row who wants to atone, and a vicar who wants to do the right thing.Unfortunately, the story is so unbelievable and contrite, with plotholes big enough to let Hannibal and his elephants go through and prepostorous dialogues.I know it is fictional drama, but you expect at least a bit of credible storytelling. I really wanted to suspend my disbelieve but everytime I tried to give in, one of the main characters dis something utterly unbelievable and ruined it for me.I watched all 4 episodes, and only realized that this mini-series was written by the same guy who wrote the screenplay for the incredible dull and disappointing "Dracula".As for the actors, I love David Tennant and Stanley Tucci, but did not find either performance up to par with their previous work.

reviews.review_title: The theme song haunts my dreams
reviews.content: It had the perfect potential for an intriguing and gut wrenching mini series but very quickly became sloppy and drowned out by poor production and musical scoring. I finishing it because I thoughtlessly assumed that the acting quality could redeem what we had lost in the plot, or at least the ending would provide something resembling closure, but no, we are left with just as many questions as we started with. What a waste of Stanley Tucci. I wonder if he's ever worked on a more limited set. Also, the dialogue ... cheeky dialogue amidst a life of death situation in the other room, provides more stress than I am willing to commit to. I'm seriously looking for redeeming qualities, but much like that flat "journalist" character, I'm really grasping as straws here.

Absolutely gorgeous! It gets so deep into human nature, but sorry to whom it may concern, I have to say this, you need to have some brains to like this show. I get the impression that audiences are used to stupid, easy to grasp shows, and everything that even remotely doesn't resemble a no brainer, urges them to leave a negative comment and low ratings. It's actually sad that everyone is so accustomed to their comfort zone, that when something different appears on the TV their dopamine just stays put. They expect everything to be perfect and explainable, but sometimes it just isn't. I loved this show, exactly because it showed that life can be ruined by simple circumstance and unfortunate chain of events.Great show, highly recommended. BUT PLEASE, try turning on your brain cells. If you're unable to do so, skip it and just don't leave any rating if you don't get the point. AND many of you just didn't!

Really, really bad. How can anyone rate this higher than 1 star? A torture to watch all 4 episodes. And for those who stopped watching after 1 or 2 episodes, good for you. The last episode is even more ridiculous than the previous ones.In the last episode I was really tempted to switch off when Ben was is the cellar talking to his dad, because of all the stupidity. First Ben is shouting to get out, then suddenly hè doesnt care anymore. Because ofcourse if the cosy cellar.That whole episode took about 60 minutes and most of it was filled with some calling and texting one another, setting alarms, a annoying vicar sitting in his chair.Like I said, really, really bad.

This is not a waste of good actors, without the good good actors, the good acting is what kept me entertained. You will find yourself screaming at the screen though.This is not a story that is believable in any way. Poor and unlikely actions, decisions, chain reactions and connections. But to me, that is not the point of it all. I see this as a dark comedy. In the middle of it all, there are so many funny moments that made it worthwhile for me. Just the whole idea that it's not actually that easy to kill someone made me laugh.Even though it was all very weird and sometimes impossible or at the very least not very likely, I found it gripping and I did want to see how it all played out and how people and storylines would be connected eventually.Enough loose ends for a second season, so looking forward to that! I love that it was just 4 episodes as well.

Inside Man is a truly special show. Everything from the acting, music, story, directing, humour is just incredible amazing. I one hundred percent absolutely recommend this show to anybody who loves dark thriller, or David Tennant 😂 The plot is quite "Moffatty" but not in a bad way. It has his usual comic relief, character based complicated writing but is all amazing. The show is available on BBC iPlayer completely for free and it is very short at just four fifty minute episode. It has moderate blood, violence and swearing but is as of yet unrated, I wouldn't recommend the show to anybody who isn't a teenager or older, depending on the maturity level of said teenager.

reviews.review_title: Ignore the bad reviews! Great show!
reviews.content: I do not understand all the bad reviews??? Stanley Tucci and his cellmate, Atkinson Estimond, are hilarious together. They play off each other so we'll and I found myself laughing out loud. It's definitely a dark comedy at times and I find it hilarious. Too many haters out there with nothing better to do than write bad reviews. The plot is one I have never seen and it shows that parents will do anything to protect their kids. Good twists and turns throughout the whole series.If you are a Stanley Tucci fan than it is a must watch. I hope more people give it a 10 to bring the ranking up because it does not deserve a 6.5..

I just finished watching the series, and I'm now irrationally irritated. I feel like my time has been wasted.Inside man is a very poorly written series with an improbable plot and ridiculous characters. It is a shame that the stellar cast was under-utilized with such a dismal script. Each character behaved in an over the top fashion and consistently made mind numbingly stupid decisions. If Moffat had thrown in a couple of slapstick jokes, I would have thought I was watching 4 episodes of, "Three's Company".Instead of a relaxing evening, I was watching the clock willing the show to quickly wrap up. Is Steven Moffat embarrassed? He should be.

I wish I hadn't bothered watching this.Stanley Tucci and David Tennant were both good as you would expect, (as was the guy who played Dillon - he was was quite funny).It started off well and we liked the first half of episode one, but that's where it ends.I didn't like Janice, Mary or Beth so found it hard to care about them and relate to them.I found that the story was a bit unbelievable and quite frustrating at times to the point I wasn't even sure I wanted to finish watching it.I feel I am left with quite a few unanswered questions too as not everything was clear to usI don't recommend this.

reviews.review_title: Even Tucci Can't Save This Terrible Series
reviews.content: Stanley Tucci does consistently great work as one the industry's most watchable actors. He should have done himself a favor and passed on this atrocious series. With the exception of his death row cellmate, very well-played by Atkins Estimont who serves as a kind of Dr. Watson to Tucci's death row kind of Sherlock Holmes, the other cast members should all be on death row with quick execution dates for butchering their performances while Tucci and his friend deserve pardons for putting up with them. Tucci's character solves mysteries from his cell with his friend's help, and does so pretty well even though his cases are lame because of the show's very poor writing. The main case involves an attempted murder run amok by a non-criminal couple (a pillar of the community as the local clergtman and his wife) who let a mistaken identity child porn situation get ridiculously out of hand. It is neither funny nor credible. I would rate every performance except for Tucci's and Estimont's and Dylan Baker's somewhere between zero and less. I never put spoilers in reviews despite wanting to do so here to keep people from watching this mess, but after forcing myself to watch all 4 episodes mainly to see what would happen to Tucci as his execution date draws near I decided not to. The rest of the plot deserves a zero for stupidity and the wrong kind of silliness, as does the direction and overall script. I never thought Stanley Tucci could make a bad movie or show, and he does not do so here because he is fairly credible as a jailhouse detective. However, even he cannot save this dog which needs to be put out of its misery. I suggest paying attention to other reviews similar to mine before committing 4 hours of time better spent on better movies and series.

reviews.review_title: Amateurish attempt to combine Silence of the Lambs sleuthing with Fargo-style humour
reviews.content: Writer Moffat seems so very pleased with himself. He seems to think that a single piece of cod-philosophy is enough to carry a four part TV series. The kind of though a first-year university student would come up with on day one of a philosophy degree. Before the actual teaching has started.As regards tone - it is all over the place. By accident, not design.The powers of deduction attributed to Stanley Tucci's Hannibal Lector-like character aren't impressive. Is success is due to chance. In each of the cases he addresses, there are many other possible occurrences that might have happened.At least it really is 'so bad it's good.' Enjoyable for committed performances from the British actors, let down by barely engaged performances from the Americans. Blame timid direction for that. Insecurity about getting good performances led to weak scene blocking and mostly unmotivated shot choices.So if they do get a second season, I will tune in - if only to enjoy how bad TV can be and despair at how amateurish British productions can be.

reviews.review_title: Bad reviews if you've never read the tragedies
reviews.content: The Greek tragedies and Shakespeare's are well known. If you don't know the genre, you'll be sitting wondering why the characters are doing bad things and shaking your head, even blaming the writers. If you see this as a tragedy, it makes sense. They're supposed to be bad actions and bad choices, the outcomes are meant to be bad. But we can look at their mistakes and see what they should have done. We can learn from others' mistakes. It's not a new genre. Everything working out well isn't that realistic. People do stupid things every day in real life. Some get away with it, some pay the price. But human folly is real. There are plenty of references to real world behaviour here.

reviews.review_title: You can write this, but you can't say it.
reviews.content: Harrison Ford famously said to George Lucas something along the lines of "you can write this, but you sure can't say it". But corny dialogue didn't harm Star Wars; it may have even added to its off-world charm. Likewise, Steven Moffat's wisecracking characters with grandiose speeches worked brilliantly during his tenure as showrunner of the equally unearthly Doctor Who as well as in his well-observed sitcom Coupling. But dramas set in the real world have become grittier and more true-to-life during the last couple of decades, and Inside Man sticks out like an unrealistic fake sore thumb with its unrelatably unusual characters spouting bizarre dialogue in even weirder situations. I'd compare it to the slightly otherworldly feel of the TV adaptations of Harlen Coben's novels, which have the same issue of dialogue that sounds perfectly fine in your head when you read the novel but sounds a bit ridiculous when you hear it coming out of someone's mouth. Inside Man has some brilliant acting talent on screen, but even they can't make the script sound like anything any real person might say. Even suspending belief and allowing yourself to be entertained will leave you with questions about the characters' motivations which also make no sense. That said, if you persevere though the first episode, you will want to finish it. The oddness does make it oddly compelling. I feel bad saying all this as I remain a huge fan of Moffat's writing; I just think he's strayed into an area that doesn't suit him. The only reason his Sherlock worked in a 'real-world' setting was by making the character an autistic savant who could speak like no neurotypical person would and still come off as believable. Inside Man is worth a go, but there's lessons to be learned from it.

reviews.review_title: If nothing else, watch if for Stanley Tucci
reviews.content: This is almost two different movies, one set in the US and the other in the UK. The UK storyline is ridiculously implausible and almost painful to watch. The US storyline, with Stanley Tucci as the central character, while also somewhat implausible, is at least fun to watch. While this is a murder drama, with details that can be a tad disturbing, Tuccl's character is witty, intelligent, acerbic, and even funny. There were times during the US scenes where I laughed out loud (although I have no idea if that was the intent of the filmmakers).David Tennant deserves better than the completely unhinged character he plays...and the thoroughly idiotic storyline he's given to work with. In fact, the UK storyline is so bad (with the exception of Lydia Wells, who is the only bright star here), that it's hard to imagine so many people acting so stupidly.Watch it for Tucci, suffer through the rest. Hell, it's only 4 parts, so you won't suffer too much.

Honestly it was a very entertaining show! Not a dull moment but it didn't make a lot of sense.Why would a priest want to ruin his own life and his family's and possibly commit murder in order to protect a confirmed pedophile?Even if you weigh the "sins" against each other murder will always be worse.The journalist girls was a poorly written character, I felt she was only on the story to con the IK to the US? Too far fetched.It was definitely worth watching on a rainy Wednesday but there's a lot of gaps in the story.And all these dumb ass people not answering their phones, see here what you get!

reviews.review_title: From lacking credibility to fascinatingly absurd
reviews.content: A great premise : a man on death row solves crimes. After this premise is clear, you enter a story that is totally ridiculously, as it really lacks any credibility. Most will probably stop watching after the first or (if you have some patience) second episode. Just check other reviews for confirmation on that.Hold on. I really was at that point after the second episode, but as this series is only four one-hour episodes long, I decided to sit it out, and was not disappointed.Though the story still lacked all credibility, I changed my perspective. The story is completely absurd and viewing it from that perspective, it definitely becomes more interesting. It has some interesting and unexpected plot twists and even the obvious plot holes become part of a completely absurd world.Greatest and well thought through characters are the man inside and his (in) mate. Let's hope they weren't executed in the end, as these characters could wel be the basis for more.The final scene (don't leave immediately when the credit titles begin) creates a completely opend end and thus future possibilities.All in all, worth you while although for any future undertaking based on this premise, I would definitely suggest a better storyline than a vicar that goes to length to protect his son from a wrongful accusation.

Stanley Tucci and Atkins Estimond clearly had better characters to work with and the writing around them seems to be done by a completely different (and sub-standard) set of writers than that given to David Tennant.Tucci's part seems to have been well thought out and knew where it was going from the beginning. The story around Tennant and his whole family was illogical and uneven. The dialog was crap. The ending was apparent from the beginning and it was like the writers were trying to figure out a way to get to that point and making stuff up as they went.While the characters on the US side come across as likable (even though they are violent murderers), the same can not be said for the folks across the pond who we seem to dislike from the very beginning.You'll find yourself drawn into the story but will probably feel unsatisfied by the end.

I don't know how many times I screamed at the tv " ARE YOU STUPID???" Tucci was the only thing worth watching. Tennet's story line was so implausible that if it were any more that 4 episodes they would have lost me. Two normal people- one of whom is a vicar for gods sake- speak so blithely about murder.Loved the dialogue between Tucci's character and his next door neighbor in prison. One thing done really well was was the wrap up. I couldn't figure how the writers were going to resolve the two disparate story lines with only one episode left.I did like the evolving character of the tutor... just when you though she was ok.....

Good actors, well acted, but I am tired of all the stories are about horrible, reprehensible people. This was uncomfortable to watch at times.I was hoping for redemption in the end for someone. Janice wasn't likeable, I didn't like the reporter either.No explanation on how the inmate came know his wife, or are they hoping for another season?This could have been so much better. The cast had such promise. With the exception of the serial killer, all the characters were well done. Of course it's hard to like any serial killer. I did like how the loop was closed at the end with how all is discovered.

To be honest I am not sure will I finish this series at all. I am half way through, skipping bits.It is so ridiculous, that even the actors don't believe saying and acting it, and it really shows.It's like over the top bad drama improvisation class. Gosh!I really expected way more, from the cast also. They are all way better.What came over them to star in this nonsense and do their job like they are so bored out their mind... I really don't get it and don't know.I really wish to finish this review if it will let me post it finally and just forget about this nuisance of a series and be done with it.

A great set of performances, across a well paced series, with some strong direction across the four episodes.If you're looking for characters who are incredibly clever rational people, I would not recommend this show, but if you like watching the least equipped people on planet earth devise how they're going to murder someone, carried by the performances of David Tennant and Dolly Wells, you should give this a watch.Not Moffat's best work, but it's oh so far from whatever catastrophe the 1 star reviews are acting like it is.Give it a watch if you're looking for a suspenseful drama, with ever raising stakes, and a slice of Stanley Tucci.

I don't even know how to rate this. It was MADDENING. I guess I'm supposed to be rooting for the imprisoned woman?? But everything that happened to her was her own damn fault and I actually wish she hadn't survived. I was rooting for her death and the vicar to get away with it the whole time. Like she's the absolute worst. I wish I could have strangled her myself. And then of course the vicar literally just had to make ONE correct choice and the whole thing would be over. He was a vicar for god sake!! Can one fricken person just use their brain?? Just maddening. The whole damn thing. The only good thing about this show was Stanley Tucci.

reviews.review_title: Good story but whacky plot holes
reviews.content: After watching all four episodes, including the after credits segment in ep4, we learn throughout that the imprisoned maths teacher is a loner, has no friends, no love life, no clubs, no dating, no mention of a husband, a rather sad person with no personal life.In the segment after the credits in ep4, she shows up to meet with Tucci's character to figure out a way to kill her...husband? Where did that come from? I wish I didn't watch that last part.We also never learn what was so special about Tucci's wife's head. He made a big spiel about how after finding her head, everyone will understand why he had to chop it off. Her face was just so horrible. Was she a vampire or something? Maddening.Sending the authorities to the Vicar's house because he figured out she was being held captive there was utterly ingenious (especially after he got a confession beat out of him).There are other plot holes that could've been rightly fixed, but I thought this was one of the better shows by Moffat. Not as good as his Dracula limited series, which I recommend everyone watch on Netflix. I can understand it's not to everyone's tastes, but I found it mesmerizing. Watched it twice.I hope Netflix does more shows with Moffat. He's very talented but needs a good story editor before it gets filmed. I see Netflix didn't get all woke with this limited series and just focused on the basics.I didn't appreciate the cracks about Christianity, calling Jesus' rising on the third day a "fairy tale" and other insults. That's the Vicar's wife saying that. Talk about a Jezebel. Completely unnecessary.Some will hate it, some will love it. But it's not as bad as many people are making it out to be and the dialogue is so much better than the crap on any channel or service. That seems to be Netflix's new motto: hire better writers, get better products. Well, duh!

So much promise! Oustanding cast, great direction and dialogue. All the makings of an entertaining and intellectual binge. All but for the ridiculous plot; it assumes the viewers are idiots and won't notice (or won't mind, not sure which is the greater condescension). It just got progressively worse-erer and worse-erer.... What? If they can peddle that rubbish, I can claim worse-erer as a real word! Tennant, Tucci et al should have sacked (or shot) the plot writer/s. The dialogue on the other hand is clever and, at times, brilliant. Sadly not enough to bring me back for another series.WhaaaaaaatTF!

The acting is good, as expected, and once you get over the unbelievability of the situation that kicks it all off you can believe that the events that unfold could happen that way. Unfortunately this show falls victim to the Moffat/Sherlock curse of "tells you it's really clever without actually being really clever" (the Stanley Tucci flashy 'Sherlock' moment at the start absolutely does not stand up to scrutiny). Last episode descends into a singular plot of "if everyone just had a conversation this would all get cleared up" which is my least favourite literature device. Didn't finish the ep.

reviews.review_title: I can't rate less than a star, unfortunately
reviews.content:
Yes, like everyone says here:
why would you NOT go to the police when you discover child porn?! Why wouldn't you tell the truth to the math teacher, explain what has just happened?what was so interesting about the journalist to the genious criminal? Afterall, it took her quite some time to understand that men in an orchestra wear a tux 😒 The killer had to spell it for her, that's how intelligent she was.the vicar's wife is mesmerized that she couldn't find on the internet how to kill a person (even though, sure you can, but this is not the point). Because yes, that's the first thing someone goes to, in a situation like theirs: how to kill. Especially someone with moral values. She then is judgemental about people who search for sex online. Those twisted pervs. They're searching for sex, which messes up her search for killing someone 😒 And she's so stressed, but manages to hold her humor, kisses her husband, the vicar, and let's us know how sexually active they are.I couldn't see more than ep 2, the plot is insulting.English is not my first language, I apologize.I don't recommend this show.

Which is more than a fair score.The actors are mostly brilliant given the material they got. The writing is off the walls terrible. The detective is so obviously a play on Sherlock Holmes with a stupid twist of him being on death row.There is only barely a story because of characters being dumber than dumb. It makes it very unbelievable and impossible to connect to the story. There is one very obvious response to the story and that is going to the police. The investigation would be fast and prove who is the culprit. That this isn't the case is the writer making the characters dumber than they would've been in real life.Best thing about the show is that there are only 4 episodes. This would be a bad movie and it is a bad tvshow, so thank goodness for it stopping at 4 episodes.

Part way through the third episode I began to suspect that this show was written by AI. There wasn't a single thing that made sense or had any continuity in the entire show, at least that part was consistent. The characters went through rapid unpredictable changes for no apparent reason only to return to their 2 dimensional profile moments later. The "cases" he "solves" make no sense and are full of holes.Overall the show comes across like an extra lite, sugar free Silence of the Lambs after school special meets an anemic, pedestrian The Green Mile but with not one likable character (aside from Janice at moments but true to form that gets ruined as well).I was cheering for all of the characters to die by the end, which is rare for me. The themes of hopeless victim-hood coupled with impotent flailing toward redemption running through the show were profoundly offensive, not in a moral way as was probably intended but in a acrid flatulent way.The theme song that plays several times through every episode, which sounded like a jeans commercial from the early aughts, is a folk song done in a vaguely "Bluesy" kind of way but with every ounce of soul or character effectively extracted and filled with plastic. In that respect I think it was the perfect selection for the series.It really seemed as if the show were written by two different people who never conversed or bothered to read the other's contribution. So this has me wondering...Is this show a test to see if the general public streaming at home are paying attention at all, a new TV series script writing AI or a money laundering scheme?I am certain I wouldn't have watched the second episode if it hadn't been a limited series. At least the show's creators had the basic decency not to waste any more of mankind's time than absolutely necessary.

All actors were really good and i enjoyed their acting. But the story is poor written. Somethings didn't make sense so much as to support the story and somethings that are happening are too much and felt pretentious. Also there was a weird portion of drama and comedy that made me not sure if I wanted to laugh or feel the drama of the character. The character of Atkinson Estimond didn't add up to what he did in the past and felt weird and unmatched but I enjoyed David Tennant's character. Overall I enjoyed the 4 episodes due to the good acting but if the show was longer I would probably stop watching it.

reviews.review_title: Ridiculous Set Up Lets it Down
reviews.content: Inside Man starts off well, intriguing... but then the incident that sets everything in motion is just stupid, poorly written, badly shot and acted. It's hard to care about the situation when it was all so avoidable.Events that happen later are also contrived, not making much sense to up the drama. The show could have been great, just needed way better directing and writing.However, I finished it and will probably check out the sequel, set up in the final moments. The good things are the acting from the main cast and the still slightly intriguing back story of Stanley Tucci's character and what he is doing playing detective.Worth watching if you have nothing else to watch, can suspend your disbelief, and are a fan of David Tennant, Stanley Tucci, or Lydia West.

Loved it. It is bonkers and weird and totally not to be taken seriously at all. This is pure entertainment. There is some inside no9 in there and the unrealistic plots as in midsomer murders with a lot of humor and great acting. Tennant at his best. There is someone here writing don,t waist your time. That is arrogance. I am perfectly capable of judging what i like or not for my own. It is better not to act on any of these negative reviews and see for yourself, because the negatives reviews for me personally were completely wrong and I would have missed a wonderfull tv show if I had given this a miss because of the majority of negative reviews. Life is serieus enough and tv shows are full of it specially with all these crime dramas (far to much of them on tv) and this is different. Different is good.

I am 100% convinced no one responsible for making this show has ever spoken to another human being. There is no other explanation for the plot holes, or leaps in logic that are the central conflicts and resolutions of this show.It's like watching a trainwreck!No character motivations make any sense. None of the mysteries have any grounding in reality. No research was done on whether things were logical. The plot is just a hot mess.The actors do a decent job with the little they were given, but even their performances can't save a show so ridfled with plot holes they may as well announce time of death.

I started watching this 4 part drama with high hopes. However I spent more questioning the plot holes which made no sense. Try as I might, I really couldn't understand how one action from a character lead to another action or conclusion. From the beginning we are lead to believe that the Stanly Tucci character had an innate ability to solve crime but his reasoning was, for me not at all convincing.All that said on a positive note it was well acted, which you would expect from a cast lead by David Tennant and Stanley Tucci and perhaps that lead me to continue watching this when I might have normally given up.

reviews.review_title: Great cast, missing some identity, still a good ride
reviews.content: I can't help but feel that this series was a mishmash of ideas from existing media like Sherlock, silence of the lambs, Fargo, etc. It can feel a bit aimless at times jumping to storylines that should've been cut.I definitely felt some padding with the journalist storyline. I honestly don't think we needed the namesake of the show at all. I think a better focus on the captive situation would've been appreciated without the need to give a useless "Holms" type crime genius dragging out answers and being mysterious.It was also weird seeing him go from chasing penance with the death sentence to fighting for a stay of execution and ultimately not receiving it.The ending felt very rushed. The wife's demise, the amount of times Tennant reconsiders that duct tape, the convenient timing of the random mercenaries to save the day. I think this one needed more time in the oven.And can I just say, Janice was surprisingly healthy for the post credits scene only 2 weeks after ALL the physical injuries she had.Either way the performances were great for the most part, David tenant carried the show despite his poor and frustrating dialogue. I wouldn't call it an essential watch but it is definitely engaging and a good little binge especially for fans of a dark fall from grace story. Turn your brain off and have a laugh at some horrible decisions.

reviews.review_title: Good Acting, Interesting Concept, Idiotic Crime Story
reviews.content: Minister And his wife become kidnappers because of a misunderstanding that could be cleared up in an afternoon by turning in the true offender. Jump drives can be traced back to the computer they were downloaded from. Easy to prove in minutes by a forensic team. Instead let's take a do-gooder vicar who is loved by his parishioners and suddenly make him assault the tutor of his child and lock her in the basement. Really? The half of the story in prison is engaging, the characters are interesting. The half that follows the crime is completely irrational. Too bad, because this could be really good. Say it was the vicar's drive and he tries to set up some poor schmuck at the church. And the genius needs to figure that out to save the parishioner. Now there's a story.

Ok, i have to admit that i did enjoy, for the most part, this limited series. A prisoner on death row in the USA and a woman trapped in a cellar under an English vicarage, cross paths in the most unexpected way. The way that the two characters cross paths is the most unconvincing way possible, however if you can overcome this point you will enjoy this series. The acting and production were great. I was an instant fan of Dolly Wells.The series trys to tackle current day issues, which is the eye rolling part. These issues always come across as forced and weak. There was also a sense of "vicker/church bashing" which I could see coming from a mile away.Overall a fun binge.

Many claimed the plot was unbelievable, but had this been a slapstick comedy then nobody would have called the plot out. The plot places the characters into situations where you see human nature play out into a comedy of errors. The characters have to question their own morals and weigh between what is right, and what is right for the ones they care about. If you can get past the absurdity of some of the situations then this is a great dark comedy watch. Great acting by all cast. Funny by the irony of situations, and funny scenes at the prison - where they are absolutely stolen by Atkins E. As the fellow prisoner.

reviews.review_title: Good acting, terrible TERRIBLE writing and plot
reviews.content: I did watch the whole thing, mostly because I kept hoping it would somehow redeem itself or become less stupid at some point. But no, it just kept getting more stupid. I honestly don't know how they got these amazing actors (who still managed to deliver good performance) to be interested in this garbage story.It was so contrived and the plot devices tired and obvious but also oh-so-dumb, none of this story made any sense. They took a problem, showed a super easy way for it to be a non-problem, and yet everyone did the exact opposite of what a person would do if faced with these obstacles.On top of that, the detective character, while it did have some charm and a bit of dark humor between him and his partner, was also completely beyond logic.It was basically like watching a very very bad play performer by good actors for some reason.

Was so looking forward to this show!Storyline jumped around a bunch which was ok but would've liked more character plots with other soldiers.Chris Pratt is not believable in this role - it's awkward to watch. Seemed uncomfortable almost within himself & the character he was playing. Chris Pratt is probably best to stay with humorous easy going character vs trying to play intense dark troubled man.Taylor Kitsch is great in his role but has very limited screen time. He's great at the ever brooding-got your back guy!I was 7eps in & when I found out he died - I stopped watching. Very disappointed.

What a load of tosh. I cannot imagine why, upon reading the script, any of the actors took this on.It starts off badly, and then gets even worse. It males the presenting on Strictly look smooth, polished and professional.Instead of explaining memory stick and going to police, the character decides it would be better to throw tutor into cellar and hold her prisoner. WTF? Why?The interaction between British journalist and the two serial killers is diabolical, cringe worthy etc.Certainly won't be watching any more of this, much prefer to watch paint drying. I think this is the most unbelievable rubbish I've ever had the misfortune to see.Why David? Why?

reviews.content: I was thrilled about the actors so i started watching it with joy. But from the half of the first episode the story sucks.
