Frustration and helplessness are the two most strongest emotions I felt while watching this show. Why would anybody would think that's an enjoyable experience is beyond me. I've seen many reviewers claim that you need a great deal of suspension of belief to enjoy this show. I don't agree at all and it sounds like a lame excuse for bad writing. There are no characters to root for here nor good mysteries to be solved (maybe why one of the inmates killed his wife but I don't really care). There is nothing to keep the viewer attention besides the chemistry between the two inmates and their wit. But again, at least Sherlock would explain how he got to make a deduction but the way the guy in this show solves the cases is not explained well and it doesn't make sense at all. I got really excited for this show because I love David Tennant but, man, what a waste of time this was.

The side of the story with Tucci in jail is very well done and is the only driving force of the show. The Tennant side is so poorly written that the amazing cast can't find a way to keep you interested.This truly is a disappointment. They take a different approach at the idea of interviewing a murderer, and the whole dynamic of the two death row inmates working together has a fun charm. Unfortunately, the other half of the show makes no sense. They build a hero in the first scene of the first episode, and that's the last time she is given anything that comes close to resembling logic.As mentioned in the subject, this show is half good. You will like the scenes with Tucci. The other scenes will feel like something written by a person that hasn't ever encountered other human beings, and you will probably start playing with your phone, walking off, etc. To kill those scenes.

reviews.review_title: I never give a 1 star but this was close
reviews.content: The only reason this is worth watching is to get drunk and laugh AT it. I don't know how this 'writer' keeps getting commissioned. Does he think himself as clever? Coz he seems to think all his extremely unclever characters are! I have had the absolute misfortune to be forced into watching this, but in a morbid way I couldn't stop. Until I found my phone and decided to write a review about what was making my eyes dry up and bleed. Nothing makes sense. Everything could have been avoided if any of the characters were actually intelligent. No one is likable. The directing is a masterclass in how not to direct, which explains why this director has a terrible repertoire. Watch it to take the piss. Don't watch it if you are sober.

This is one of the weirdest series I have watched . WTF? Too much David Tennant and not enough Stanley Tucci. The whole back and forwards of this I found totally confusing for the first two episodes. Despite this I found it reasonably compelling just to see what happened. Many people will give up on it. Have to say I have watched a lot better. Great actors in a very confusing and unconvincing plot. David Tennant is his usual scruffy self and meant to be credible as a Vicar. Stanley Tucci is the star of the show. Like a Hannibal Lector on death row. This won't be everyone's cup of tea. You will wonder why you invested so much time.

The plot of this series is based on an idea said more than once by the main character: we are all murderers, all it takes is a good reason and a bad day! Through bad luck, a truly..very...bad one!, and the accumulation of bad deeds , most of them are done for obvious good reasons, a monster is born! The show is captivating, and leaves the audience confused, because you can not take the aching question out of your mind: if I am to be put in the same situation, would I do something different?Those who hated it mostly based their hate on (it is unbelievable...this can not happen!) but the truth is: unfortunately...this could happen! And the world has a significant number of psychopaths, murdereres, rapists and bloody criminals wandering in its streets, and if you ask any of them: why?? Mostly they would reply: I had to!The performance is outstanding...Stanely Tucci is marvelous. Dolly wells shines. David Tennant, the vicar, was so convincing.Inspite all that, I have to admit that I refuse that message, and I truly believe that most of people are good and when they are tested by the cruelty of the world, they will show love and understanding more than anything else.....but, again, this is a smart and thought provoking show.

Should be called "A Series of Unfortunate Events" 😂😂 The protagonist gets it wrong at every turn, it's getting slightly ridiculous towards the end, though there's a moral message in this story. The clever inside man is an entertaining twist, but adds little to the story. The American - English setting is a bit unsettling, doesn't really stick. It was entertaining though and I stayed engaged until the end. The production is nice and the actors are great, especially the protagonists on both sides. Not all of the cast was stellar though and some of the plot twists were ludicrously absurd. Solid limited series all in all.

BBC working with Netflix? Steven Moffat, David Tennant, and Stanley Tucci? Sign me up!Maybe I expected too much. The idea was a fun one, but the execution was awful.I'll start with Tenant's character, Harry. He's a vicar who doesn't put much into it. He jokes at the beginning about working one day a week, and he never comes across as the spiritual sort. He seems more annoyed at Edgar, the verger, and his little p*rn problem than sympathetic. Any semi-normal human being, let alone a religious leader, would be horrified to learn that guy is hiding child p*rn. Instead, Harry assaults and kidnaps a woman, put his entire family at risk, and in the end decides to kill someone, all because he's afraid Edgar might kill himself if anyone finds out. Dude, just call the cops and get Edgar help. I get that people make dumb decisions in the heat of the moment, but they have to make sense from the character's perspective. Harry had zero reason to do any of this. Also, the whining about "this isn't my fault, this isn't anyone's fault" was obnoxious. I still love David Tennant. He did the best with what he had to work with. But not even he can turn steaming trash into something enjoyable.Next we have Grieff, Stanley Tucci's character. This plot line was less annoying, but only by comparison. I loved the banter between Grieff and Dillon because the actors were so strong, not because the story was. Grieff is an irritating character who considers himself intellectually superior. Instead of revealing how he figures things out, he makes everyone guess and talks down to them. I'm sure this was a nod to Sherlock Holmes, but unlike Sherlock, Grieff drags it out to painful lengths. It's implied that Grieff was a stand-up citizen until he brutally murdered his wife. The warden says he doesn't understand how someone like Grieff could end up on death row. Yet Grieff has a network of criminal acquaintances that do his bidding without question. This is never explained. The whole song and dance about Grieff hiding his wife's head, which would reveal the reason he killed her? Also never explained. The story misses its chance to drive home the theme of "anyone can become a murderer under the right circumstances" by refusing to explain Grieff's motives.Beth, the journalist, was all over the place. In the beginning, she's a shrinking violet who's scared speechless in the face of a confrontation on the train. Then she becomes a hard-boiled journalist who'll get the story no matter what, even sacrifice her friend. After that, she loses definition entirely, becoming a pawn in Grieff's games.Janice, the tutor, had potential. I kept expecting her clever manipulation of Harry and his wife to lead somewhere. It didn't. She had no influence on the outcome of the story and ended up being nothing but a plot device trapped in the basement.Ben, Harry's son, tried to bludgeon Janice to death with a hammer. We're supposed to believe carbon monoxide poisoning made him go crazy. That's not how it works. It can cause confusion, but it doesn't turn you into a murderous psychopath.How does such amazing talent end up getting shoved into random nonsense like this?

reviews.review_title: A thrilling, hilarious, and morally ambiguous ride
reviews.content: The star of the show is the wonderfully suave and intelligent Stanley Tucci, who is awaiting execution for strangling and dismembering his wife. Grieff has teamed up with the sociopathic serial killer Dillon Kempton to solve mysteries in the most unconventional of ways. The chemistry between Grieff and Kempton is amazing, and their banter is hilarious, making them worthy of their own spinoff series.There is also the story of the hapless vicar, Harry Watling who finds himself in a situation that could ruin his family's life. To protect Edgar, a troubled, suicidal man working at his church, Harry takes a flash drive with some unsavory content (child pornography, as he later finds out) off his hands, and it mistakenly ends up with his son's math tutor, Janice. Unable to convince Janice that it does not belong to anyone in the family and afraid that she will go to the police if freed, Harry takes the interesting course of action of locking Janice in his basement until he can decide what to do. The tension builds thrillingly as Harry gets further and further sucked into his own mistakes.Their paths cross when investigative journalist Beth Davenport visits Grieff in prison under the suspicion that her "friend" Janice is missing. But despite her being an investigative journalist, we only see her driven around at the whim of Grieff as he sends her off to look for clues for his various cases with the help of the shadow army he has working for him across the globe. Beth spends most of the series with a confused look on her face as other characters take action all around her.The linkage between the two stories is clear thematically. Tucci's version of a murderer is so likable that the audience, and the characters themselves, wonder how he could have killed someone so brutally. But as he tells Beth in a calm, seductive voice, "Everyone is a murderer; all it takes is a good reason and a bad day."Good people are driven to do bad things. The pedophile is tortured by his dark instincts, the vicar is nearly driven to insanity by his desire to be good, and Janice, the supposed hero of the story, is found to be conniving, manipulative, and unlikeable. And Grieff, as charming as he is, is still a murderer, and we never find out why he kills his wife.The effect of all this moral ambiguity is comedic. It is a rare show that would have benefited from a longer run of episodes, or at least a more carefully constructed setup. But if you are in the mood for quality acting, mindless thriller fun, and a healthy dose of moral ambiguity, then give this a shot.

Such a good cast, and not a bad concept, but so badly executed. I suppose it was supposed to be something like "Silence of the Lambs", but logic follow up was so bad. So many gaps in the story, it seems like they have cut out so much, it feels unfinished. Particularly the end of it.Character abilities and situation explanation is so badly done, it keeps you hoping until very end that there will be some sense in all of it.And seems as realistic as Marvel characters. I mean, it wasn't enough that bloke on death row is being given tasks to solve from prison, but he is given possibility to shleph with him another one in order to be his living memory? Yet he is masterminding everything on another side of the ocean, through the telephone?

reviews.review_title: Lamest series of events which make no sense! This can't be normal Moffat
reviews.content: Circumstantial events which make no sense at all.You meet someone one a subway and you're just obsessed with finding her that you're pretending to be her flat mate, there is no limitation of resources to a struggling reporter, the guy in the US has someone shady working for him in London; even after causing a death on the street she's just obsessed with that acquaintance/unknown friend,the stupid father when confronted by his son is lying to him straight faced and he's just the dumbest character ever written.Why would you avoid a call to see it after 5 mins to be distracted again by something.

Ok. Do people really believe what is happening here? The race reversal of course is deliberate. Anyone who has ever spent a bit of time on public transport in London knows that the problem isnt with young black girls getting sexually harassed off white boys. It's absurdly ridiculous, but everyone pretends otherwise, then drop in a bit of 'toxic masculinity'To change it around it. Maybe in some circumstances this could be classed as subversive. But it isnt, it's jsut tired old tv tropes. All the tv does it now, in an attempt to 'uplift marginalised voices' we have to all fall into this collective delusion that the truth is the opposite of what we know it is.

Admittedly I'm only on episode 2 but I am really enjoying this drama. Dark humour and good acting. The characters are extreme but that's part of it for me. A very good fictional drama. I think how the storylines are playing out and interacting with each other are very good. Janice is brilliant, I think she is on the autistic scale and plays it brilliantly. The dialogue from Stanley Tucci is so well written and the vicar and his wife don't play the stereo typical image of a clergy family. Don't understand the bad reviews at all. Give it a go, it's a story, it's not supposed to be real life but close enough to be believable.

I'd say for the most part the acting here is pretty good. The story line tho is where I get lost. There are lots of disjointed stories and you aren't really sure if they are blending or separate. And there are some extremely uncomfortable scenes that I don't think were really necessary. I mean maybe that's what they were going with the series but the way the priest was so unnecessarily aggressive and lying. Like why even try to hide something for someone you know is a pedophile. Why not immediately call the police instead you have to lie for a pedophile then chase down a woman and man handle her. Also the cut scenes with Tucci in jail as a lawyer I honestly didn't get the point and I'm not sticking around to find out. I can handle some awkward scenes but this clearly was designed to make you feel uncomfortable. No thanks. I already have to work a 9-5 I don't need to watch something so gross.

How is it that the people behind the other 'Inside' (Inside No 9) can, within 30 minutes, create much juicier twists and, above all, much more believable ones than what the characters in this 4 episode grind were forced to execute.Now the premise about a death row prisoner able to solve crimes is wonderful, the acting is amazing, direction spot on. All the elements are there, but within literally the first minutes people are doing things no normal person would ever do, just to provide a setup. It continues getting more and more agonising as nobody acts the way any sane person would, clearly written to do things just to advance the plot. Meanwhile huge and unbelievable jumps of deduction are made from within a prison cell.4/10 is charitable for what this is, mainly due to technical merit and for the concept. But it was a painful march to the conclusion which was ultimately not very satisfying.

I was so excited to watch this; the cast alone, David Tennant, Stanley Tucci, Dolly Wells, Lydia West, meant that this limited series had great potential. The writer, however, Steven Moffat, not so great.Since the fiasco that was the last series of Sherlock, Moffat has really gone down my estimation as a writer. Alas, I thought to give him another chance; after all, it's been so many years since the last Sherlock.Great opener; fantastic 1st episode, skilfully setting up the scene, characters and diagetic world, (a classic old Moffat writing, if you will).By the second episode everything went down the drain...and it kept going with scene afte scene; a relentless cacophony of charcater development, caricature-esque plot twists...other members of the household gave up on it...I thought to keep watching, afterall there only a few episodes, and how bad can it get? And yet it did get worse.This forms a great example as to why Steven Moffat has messed up Sherlock so spectacularly.... I am not sure that he can trully be brilliant on his own...something tells me that when he was collaborating with Russel T Davies, that was his best work.

reviews.review_title: Worst four hours I've ever wasted
reviews.content: Trust me when I say this I give every show a fair shake and I'm never this harsh, but this was absolutely terrible. These four hours dragged as if they were 40. Do not waste your time. Watch anything and it will be better than this drivel.The only reason I even gave this a chance was because of Stanley Tucci and he is not at fault for this trash that they put on Netflix. Tucci should have been focused more on with his backstory, but unfortunately it all got entangled with the vicar, Janice the math teacher and then the Vickers son. The storyline dragged when it did not need to and this could have all been solved in an 85 minute movie. Shame on them for dragging this out for four hours!

reviews.review_title: Lots of wonderful and devastating twists and turns with engaging performances
reviews.content: While I will agree that there were some convenient situations used to drive the plot forward that other reviewers judged as completely implausible, I will also say that they were within the realm of possibility. For the reviewers that complained that the Vicar didn't just come clean to the authorities, they are obviously unaware of the confidential nature of that profession. I will also agree that Tucci acting as detective to outsiders while on death row is a reach, but Silence of the Lambs didn't receive such criticism for a similar arrangement. Also, do those who are intolerant of this also deride cash cow superhero movies where bulletproof heroes fly, breathe underwater, regrow limbs, etc.? I think not. Watch this series for the in predictable plot twists and great performances. It is excruciating at times, but a ride worth traveled.

I made it halfway through episode three before finally calling it quits. I am a huge Stanley Tucci fan, so I hung on the hopes that the writing would somewhere improve to a point worthy of his talent. Unfortunately, there are several other really good actors in this as well and they are all delivering as well as can be expected, which is something to say when what they are asked to deliver is completely unbelievable nonsense. I am obviously not using unbelievable in the colloquial sense of wonderful, but in the literal sense of incomprehensible. The storyline seems to have been written by someone who knows nothing of either human nature or how the modern world works. Starting off with the scene of the thin-thing young tough on the train who is trying to intimidate a young woman who looks quite capable of giving him a good bounce, followed quickly by the nonsense of same skinny boy somehow intimidating yet another girl into handing him her phone, followed by the tough old broad pretending to video him on "facebook live" being some sort of threat, as if the whole world is tuned in to her facebook timeline. All of which might have been forgiven in service of setting up a story line, except that the endless parade of people acting unnaturally and doing things that make no physical as well as emotional sense just keeps piling up; non-sequitur upon that's-not-how-that-works, upon non-sequitur upon that's-not-how-that-works until one cannot hope to suspend disbelief with even a Herculean effort to do so.Is there any writer, director, or creative person in the business today who has the professionalism and maturity to have their work edited by anyone with some knowledge of the things used in their work? How can anyone today be so unfamiliar with the internet, computers, and social networking even though they wish to use it as a main point in their tale? Steven Moffat might as well write about deep-sea lithium mining. He may have more knowledge of how that actually works.Four stars for actors who deliver lines well, no matter how idiotic they really are.

reviews.review_title: I tried to enjoy but couldn't.
reviews.content: Tucci's storyline and character engaged me. However I found this incredibly frustrating. I had to skip through parts, yes I wanted to find out what happens and yes that's a sign of something good. Having to skip through scenes is another thing. It felt abit all over the place. I found myself just getting annoyed at every character. I couldn't understand why the vicar would want to protect the "vulnerable pedofile" instead of protecting the children. His moral dilemma was totally confusing. I understand what he was going for, but unfortunately I just couldn't enjoy it. I appreciate when something is meant to be hard to watch but this just wound me up. The flicking back and forth between the storylines didn't keep my interest but instead just made it feel messy in parts. Don't get me wrong it's not awful, it's not the worst acting or writing I've seen by a mile. It is just utterly frustrating. It felt like he had lots of good ideas that were mashed up into one. I wish there was more character development.

Yet another psychological thriller from the BBC that is hugely disappointing, over acted and so pathetically implausible that I am beginning to think that fairies do exist at the bottom of my garden. Stephen Moffat has finally over reached himself in the dialogue and needs to stick with those si-fi themes.The plot is laughable and not in a good way either. It meanders between farce, tragedy and deviancy in one go. The varied storylines are confusing and yet their resolution defies belief and the viewer is left very unfulfilled. Personally the first five minutes of episode one with the train scene was as good as it got.I hope there is no reason two as I would fall asleep. Definitely not David Tennant's final hour.

Great stand alone performances by David Tennant and Stanley Tucci. But the whole thing didn't seem to work as a whole peoce of drama. The two separate locations of the story were brought together by very lose far fetched writing, so much so it felt more like science fiction that a kitchen sink drama. You feel for David Tennants preist initially but then just get bored of the stupidity of the and bad judgement of the character. It honestly felt like it went on too long even thought it wasn't actually that long. Couldn't put my finger of what didn't work, probably the story telling, who knows or cares.

The only people worth watching were the wife-killer and his black sidekick. The vicar, his wife and son and everyone else were awful. I was actually glad when the vicar's wife got run over - a moment of clarity at last! Indecisiveness was the watchword, and stupidity was rampant. I have never given a review before, but this was so bad that I felt compelled towarn the rest of civilization. There was nothing to tie the various characters together, the viewer was supposed to decide for him/herself what the connections are. It was 4 evenings I will never get back in my life. If I see a show with any of these actors in it, I will turn the tv off and go read a book.

There were HUGE holes in the plot. Never mind driving a truck through them, these holes could be measured in parsecs! Mr Tennant, Ms Marshall and the always wonderful Ms Wells did an outstanding job of making this work, but there were just so many points where the viewer had to suspend their disbelief that I ended up shouting at the TV even more than I usually do. Spoiler alerts: a vicar, especially a young-ish and socially aware vicar, would not try to hide some porn on a memory stick - he would either call the police once he knew what it was, or simply smash the stick with a stone. The business of Janice in the cellar trying to convince the son to call the police - well, that was a joke. The very second he saw that she was handcuffed, he would have dialed 999. Nobody is that stupid or credulous. I watched it because I wanted to know what happened, and that's a tribute to some fine actors, but the writing needed some urgent attention!

Inside Man held such promise, but it was entirely disappointing. Stanley Tucci and his death row neighbor were great. However, everything that happened in the UK part of this show was completely idiotic, implausible, and simply made no sense. I was so disappointed because I love David Tennant and Stephen Moffat's other work. The woman who plays the math tutor was also great. However, there were so many decisions made by the UK characters that didn't make sense for any of the characters to choose and yet they did. It completely ruined what might've been an amazing show. However, even the whole "bald bad guy helps solve crimes" is the same premise as Blacklist. The standout performance is by Tucci's death row neighbor, played by Atkins Estimond. Can we please get a whole show of him, instead of this garbage?

This the most implausible thing I've seen Tennant in and he played Dr Who!Shame really because I had high hopes, synopsis sounded great but the story was poor.Dialogue was ok, but it's desperately trying to be clever. It feels like they had a beginning and and end but filled it with tenuous links and back stories to paste it together.The hanibal lecter character is annoyingly smug, in fact there is a distinct lack of sincerity with every character. The writing tries to be witty, and smart but outside of Tennant and the main convict guy the acting poorly delivers it, to the point it becomes awkward.Stupid really.

Brilliant!The darkly hilarious plot glorifies human stupidity to exasperating proportions...and I was inexplicably hooked. I desperately had to know what happened next.Who doesn't love a good, fictional murder mystery with twists? Moffat's wicked understanding of the human condition is beautifully exploited in this rollercoaster of a miniseries.Always fascinated to watch shows or movies with a combination of American and British actors. This show did not disappoint. Sad to see many bad reviews, especially when I thought the writing and the talented lead actors in it were entertainingly wonderful.

Preposterous, implausible and most of all unacceptably offensive. And not just because it's the type of drama where the ending is conceived first, but the writer is incapable of anything other than shoehorning in unbelievable actions from its characters as the plot unfolds. In addition, the overarching theme-anybody is capable of killing someone given the right circumstances-is simply banal. Yes, there is some brief entertainingly light but grizzly banter between a sociopathic Holmes-and-Watson-like duo who are on death row for murdering women. But at heart this is no comedy, not when the precipitating crime concerns child sexual abuse.I only lasted one episode, feeling dowsed in unrepentant non-creative creepiness. I concluded that the only reason for the vicar's guarding the memory stick with child porn on it was because he was an accomplice to the child abuse. Based upon the spoiler reviews it appears thankfully this is not so. Because if it was, the whole drama would feel even more stomach turning, as much as child abuse pretending to be simply pornographic.In the end this four-parter is an exercise in careless creativity where nothing makes sense in terms of plot, character, mystery and both human or inhuman motivation.

reviews.review_title: It was almost great, but too many plot holes sunk it.
reviews.content: This series had so much potential to be great, and if it wasn't for the poorly judged plot holes and disappointing ending, I would be recommending it to others.I will say that the acting was excellent, the pacing was great, and the script (minutes the beyond stupid choices that made zero sense) was entertaining enough.The whole thing was far too frustrating to watch. It was hard to make it through to the end. Every character made decisions that only existed to further the plot, even though the decisions were down right implausible. There were SO many ways all the drama could have been avoided, and any person with half a brain would have been smarter about it.Mr. Griefs ending was...well....dissapointing. I'm not sure why the trend is to end a show with unfinished stories at the moment. What's wrong with tying things ups? And don't even get me started on the completely unnecessary posted credits scene. What even was that?

reviews.content: I read reviews that said it was horrible but I watched anyway! All in one day! I couldn't stop watching! I think, I will probably re-watch it, after awhile, and let all the little things soak in!Read reviews that said it was horrible but I watched anyway! All in one day! I couldn't stop watching! Moffat has always been a hit or miss writer. When he is good he's very very good when he is bad he's awful. Sadly this is the latter. A great first 10 minutes then it just gets silly. I like silly but this try's wears the clothes of something clever. It isn't it insults the intelligence of the watcher. The characters are unbelievable. The actors,( and what a cast it is) try there best but are unconvincing.I lasted 30 minutes in the hope that Moffat could pull it back under control but he didn't. Shame.Two stars is a very low score but it would have been 1 if I hadn't enjoyed the beginning as much.Do yourself a favour give this a miss.

This just showed up on netflix in germany and because of the people involved we thought this should really be up our ally.But it was painful and we only finished it to see how bad it gets in the end.Had a few laughs in the final episode but probably not what the creators intended.The tucci plot was ok and the premise might work for a simple buddy detective show with the twist that they are deathrow inmates and maybe some quirky sidekicks on the outside for the legwork.Give them 1-2 cases an episode and it would be entertaining....What really sinks the ship is the UK Plot tho. I love almost all the actors involved but the plot was just bad and the further the story goes it just made less and less sense.For example, Janice believes the son is into child porn because of a usb-drive and he even telling her that its his (he does this because he thinks its "normal" porn, belongs to his dad and wants his permission to go to a music festival, so he takes the blame).If Janice wouldn't know the son at all this premise "might" work but the way the son is arguing that its his (haha yeah its mine, don't make a fuss, just porn) should definitely make her think twice and listen to the arguments of tennents character afterwards. Later in the show we even get some flashbacks with janice and the son where it shows that they have a deeper relationship and she is a person of trust in his live.This just doesn't make any sense... and her character is otherwise portrayed to be be so cunning and smart.The whole issue could have been resolved in a few minutes after the discovery of the drive and its content like: ok you take the drive and go to the police with a taxi. I (tennant) will follow you in my car and we will discuss it there. The owner of the stick definitely had issues (beside the pedophilia) like the issues with his mother who tortures him at least mentally... It would be in his and the community best interest to get him out of that house and the mental treatment he needs.But what is tennent doing?Arguing its his stick and when she doesn't believe him and thinks he only wants to protect his child? Well how about locking her up in the basement, that will make her see reason...Tennent later also tries to get a confession out of the real owner of the drive. After intimidation doesn't work he wants to take the blame again... Why? The "boy/man" definitely needs help. But ruining your live and that of your family is still the best option? Wtf...I don't even want to mention that this stupid card house of lies would break down immediately with a forensic investigation of the drive, it contents and the families computers.All those weird and stupid decisions piled up more and more. It was just infuriating...I get the idea the show wanted to portray... anyone could become a murder but the plot they are presenting us for this scenario just has more holes in it than any Swiss cheese. If tennents character would also believe it was his sons usb-drive and they would have changed the sons character enough to make this believable it might work but then the idea of the show would be somehow lost anyway because its not a normal family anymore.I would advise anyone to stay way from this unless you get a kick out of infuriating characters and plots.3 Stars for the entertaining tucci parts only.

Well, for 2 episodes I was kinda hooked. But along the 3rd... I was getting bored. At no 4 I could not watch any longer and quit. They turned a potentially good plot into childish acting and unrealistic scenes and story. Nope, another misfit from Netflix! I have to make more scentences for my review is too short. Strange... the shorter the message, the Better I think... so What more can I tell you on this 1 star series. Well.. it's boring. And Netflix is not as good as it was so we are contemplating on leaving it and get another streaming service. Maybe HBO, maybe Disney. Or... nothing. That would save some precious time! :)

So many things that annoyed me in this show:0) I won't even start talking about the plot. It was bad in so many ways. Just focusing on annoying details.1) Beth's character. After her acting like she did in the train I could not believe her to be a badass journalist, just couldn't. Not blaming anybody for reacting like this in that kind of situation, but it doesn't fit with her character being so badass and all.2) funny sidecharacter being a serial killer who killed 15 women? Why would anyone write that? At least make him feel like he is a very unlikeable person. But no, he is just a funny guy cracking jokes, disgusting.3) Janice being so smart and all, would she really believe Ben would give her a stick with that kind of stuff on it and then act like it's nothing? Like it's just regular porn? Doesn't it ring a bell that maybe Ben doesn't really know whats on it. Does Janice really think that he is so dumb and would not at his age understand that it's not okay to have this kind of material (if it were actually his).4) Janice is just super annoying, I just can't help it.The best part is that this show was only 4 episodes.

reviews.review_title: A True Testament to Great Actors
reviews.content: If you're wondering why I gave it such a low score with such a positive title, read it again.This show is a parade of dumb unrealistic characters who put themselves in utterly implausible situations for the sake of moving the narrative along, and that's just due to awful writing. And yet... Many people have attested to being hooked. I'm the same! I watched all four episodes and, while I'm happy there aren't any more, I have to attribute being interested all thanks to the brilliance of. David Tennant and Stanley Tucci, who I really hope did this irredeemable project just for the paycheck.I mean, they must have seen it in the script, right? Stanley's character and his co-star, played by. Atkins Estimond were the best thing of this show. I kept wanting the narrative to go back to them. Their chemistry was wonderful. The female characters in this show are horribly written. Either they're irrationably defenseless and clueless or they're sadistic for no reason. David Tennant's character has the weirdest moral code I've ever seen and makes the dumbest decisions that defy reason. A murderer on death row has a better moral code than he does, but thanks to being such an amazing actor, he.manages to trudge through the fetid mud that is this writing and brings us alive to the other side. Both David and Stanley should get awards for making this garbage very much watchable.

I had such high hopes. I liked Stanley Tucci and his cell mates camaraderie. The cell mate was hilarious. I was really invested in learning what lead to Tucci killing his wife. The story of the Vicar and Janice, they could've kept that whole plot. It was boring and totally implausible. The Vicar's wife, Mary, was annoying. Tucci sends the journalist, Beth, on all of these random field trips to prove how clues are everywhere, if only people would stop and pay attention. But, yet, after 4 episodes and the conclusion of the series I still never learned what I wanted to know.... Why did Tucci's character murder his wife?!? This was 4 hours of my life wasted!

reviews.review_title: Did you get? what Greaves actually did???
reviews.content:
I loved this 4 part series
Very clever script.And because of the script being so good, it brought out the best in the actor's.And the audience is led to believe that Greaves strangled his wife & mutilated her body,- which is the main reason why he is termed a psychopathic monster.I have a theory to this though.When the audience is introduced to the father, we learn that the father is a mob criminal & may be a psychopathic monster himself. And that he & Greaves were once, very close, inferring that Greaves was also a member of the mob.So, my belief is, that Greaves wife, actually hung herself, in shame of being involved with a criminal family.Thus causing Greaves to realise that he & the father caused her death.And, so as not to shame her, he cuts up her body to make it look like he murdered her & to revenge the father ,who is an evil man.This is my theory only, as the series doesn't actually confirm this.

reviews.review_title: Worst plot I've ever wasted any time on
reviews.content: The writers of this abomination should be ashamed. The high level idea behind this is pretty decent, and the acting is actually quite good, but the whole UK storyline is so preposterous that there's nothing the actors can do to save this. It's almost like they've written it deliberately bad so that people will have strong reactions to it!I enjoy twisty-turny-contrived crime dramas as much as the next person, but gave up half way through the second episode, and will be unlikely to come back to it.So, this vicar is prepared to assault and imprison - and consider murdering - the tutor instead of giving up the child porn addicted member of his congregation. His wife also seems ok with this. None of them seem to even for a second consider that they could just release her, allow her to go to the police, and probably only face relatively minimal consequences.Stanley Tucci is enjoyable to watch, but his storyline is not all that much better. He makes such monumental assumptions in order to deduce what's going on from almost no information, that it is bordering on supernatural - at least if this was some kind of magical/fantasy show, that would explain some of the utter daftness - although as I said previously, I'm only into the second episode, so maybe it will be.

First time reviewer here, I watched this show and just really had to share my thoughts on it. And let me tell you, these thoughts are not good ones.I decided to give this a chance down to two things: the actors and the writer. I like Tennant and Tucci and have enjoyed most roles they've played. I enjoyed Moffat's writing in Sherlock but series 4 (aside The Lying Detective) was arguably not his best work and I did not enjoy Dracula. I was therefore worried how this show would turn out, and boy was it bad.Where to start? Let's look at the only positive, I believe the actors did their best with what they were given. The performances were okay but with the script they had I don't think even the best actors could make it any better.Speaking of script, has Moffat ever seen an actual human conversation before? No person interacts like anyone does in the show. The interactions are so stilted and unnatural and borderline on cringe at some points. Everyone sounds too scripted and the immersion is completely ruined.I have to admit that the first 15 minutes or so caught my attention. I won't go too much into spoilers, but let's say it turns very very unfeasible quite quickly.The whole situation could have (and in the real world would have) been resolved in about 10 minutes. Instead, we see Tennant's character take the most illogical and completely stupid route possible. All it took was the truth and a call to the police and it would have been fine. But no, instead Tennant's character who is a vicar (yes a VICAR) opts to protect a pervert and implicate himself and his son. WHY?The rest of the show continues along the same string of insane reasoning and gets no better. I haven't got much to say about Tucci's character as that's a whole new bag of problems with stupidity as you would imagine. I'm sure people on Death Row can just do what they fancy whenever they want right? The directing doesn't add anything to the show either. It's not bad but it's just nothing special in the slightest. The ending is obviously begging for a season 2 but I don't care enough to watch it.In short, it's implausible and just plain stupid. If you were hoping the actors and writers previous work would make this show worthwhile, then you will be left disappointed.

The show's overarching theme focuses very heavily on 'anyone can be a murderer' which I think is a valid point, but a huge problem is that until the very end we are shown that Greif is a 'monster' what he did was not just by stress or circumstance, unlike the vicar who did indeed almost become a murderer trying to protect his family. I don't think this was precisely what the show was going for, but the last episodes dialogue suggested murderers should be afforded some humanity, when really that's a very surface level conclusion to come to. I think that's my main issue, is that the premise had the potential to be clever and a complex insight to human nature, but the dialogue often came across as unnatural, the 'mystery' was revealed to be guess work, and for a commentary on life, was very out of touch with how humans actually act. I decided to write a review as I actually enjoyed a lot of the show, the actors were great, I was invested in the characters and their outcomes, and I do recommend the watch, just for their talent alone. This is a great series if you want something interesting to watch, but don't want to pay attention to the details.

Our family was really looking forward to watching this intriuging series. Unfortunately the experience fell way short of what was promised. I understand that the writers are trying to show how 'normal' people can be driven to committ terrible criminal acts, given the right circumstances, but the events and scenarios are SO improbable as to be entirely unconvincing.Nevertheless, Stanley Tucci and David Tenant do their best with an absolutely awful script (and it did leave me wondering if the actors realized they were taking a hefty fee knowing they were going to be acting out a lemon!! (Some of Tucci's intellectual brainteasers are absolutely laughable. Pay the-rapist!!! A schoolyard level joke!!)
All in all it was very dissapointing viewing.

Banging on basement door with bare hands instead of using a hard object or banging on ceiling or a pipe. It's too bad. The writers could have solved these dilemmas with a little bit of work. Buy a burner phone for those tasks. They certainly used characters against each other well enough. I hope they come back though! It was really great until the raw fist door banging when he could have used the hammer.

reviews.review_title: Might be brilliant, but probably really bad
reviews.content: My guess is they were going for over-the-top bonkers parody, with a ridiculous premise, intense and unearned musical score. But most of the time it felt like a CBS procedural that for rejected for not being slick enough (which, let's be honest, is a compliment). Everything about this is silly and unbelievable, nothing more so than the loveable serial killer who acts, quite literally, as the quirky next door neighbor in the vein of of an 80s sitcoms - isn't serial killing a hoot?!!?If it had committed more fully to the absurdity, then maybe it would be worth watching. But as it is, it just sits in this nowhere land between an episode of Elementary and.... I don't know...Is there a good serial killer sitcom out there? Maybe turn Urkle into a Jeffrey Dahmer-type character: "Did I do that?!" he'd ask, covered in the blood of his victims. The audience would roar with laughter and the scene would fade to black.

reviews.review_title: Hate to say it, but not great
reviews.content: I'm on episode 2, and I'm watching for the Sherlock-type crime solving that Grieff does. But there's a technical point that I, a not-very-technical person, keep coming back to. Can't someone use the metadata on the flash drive to figure out that it really belongs to Edgar? There would still be other things to address, like why the vicar had the flash drive; but it seems like it would be easy to prove that Edgar's computer saved those images, and when he saved them. If the series proves me wrong, I'll come back and update this review. But this detail is completely taking me out of the moment. Shame, because it has a good cast and potential.
