Why not just be honest with police from start and explain about the creepy vester perv and the memory stick!? One look at that sweaty mummy's boy weirdo would show the guilt. Dumb. Nice idea trying to take two completely different shows and merge together but in reality confusing, incredulous, ridiculous and frustrating. Not hatable but I'm glad it was only four episodes.Some class talent but wasted here. Think Stephen Moffat should stick to Dr Who or have chucked some cyber men into this shambles!.

I love Stanley, believe he is an awesome actor, so I watched this only because i trust his choice in roles. Show didn't disappoint, not too much anyway, but certain parts of plot unraveling could have been done with more thought put into it. Very entertaining show, don't get me wrong, loved watching it, but I prefer my stories tightly wrapped up and logical. Anyhow, well worth the watch and time spent. Interesting, fun to watch and well acted. Plot spiralling out of control was fun to watch, but choices made by actors did not seem like logical ones. Anyhoo...hope you enjoy it as much as I did. Ta.

The main idea behind the show, that everyone is capable of murder given the right circumstances, is a concept that David Tennant's fan will be extremely familiar with because Alec Hardy expresses that same thought in Broadchurch, though the circumstances there are entirely different. Anyone interested in human psychology and deviant behaviour would be attracted to the idea, as I was. Unfortunately, what surrounds it is at times hard to describe.There are a number of issues connected to the plot. First of all, there's the convicted prisoner's angle - suspension of disbelief is something that I can do, but not when you are adding a number of problematic and impossible-to-believe elements on top of each other, layering them until there's very little left that the viewer can believe.To give a minute and non-spoilery element as a focal point to this, let's look into the fact that Dillon Kempton (played by Atkins Estimond) is told to be Grieff's (played by Stanley Tucci) recorder because he has eidetic memory, and as such remembers every conversation he's ever witnessed forever. While it is a common misconception perpetrated by shows such as Inside Man, who happily misconstrue true facts to suit their purposes, a simple search on wikipedia would tell Moffat that: a) eidetic memory is connected to visual, not auditory information, b) that the length of time for which the information is recorded is not indefinite, and c) it is mostly recorded in children and not in adults. (A short, and scientific valid read that could clarify point (c) at the very least, and in some small measure point (a) can be found on Scientific American, though it cannot be linked here).The one above is, admittedly, a small detail, but it is by no means the only one. Indeed, the plot seems to be built on altogether unsteady and contrived elements, making the plot itself untenable.Characters and dialogue might rank higher than the plot, but at times they also fall short.We are meant to strongly emphasise with Janice (played by Dolly Wells), but from the get go I was unable to do so. This is not, as far as I'm concerned, the actress' fault, but simply the way the character was written and the way she speaks. As a woman myself, I did not once feel the need to protect her; she makes a string of choices which are wrong not just mistakenly but willfully, she forces characters who are good into making terrible decisions, and this, I think, corrupts the entire point of the plot. The 'right circumstances' are corrupted from the premise until they become a parody of themselves.Another point against characters is connected to Edgar (played by Mark Quartley) and his mother Hilda (played by Tilly Vosburgh). The relationship there and the circumstances surrounding Edgar's character could have been exploited further (in fact, they could have been the pivotal focus of a much better show), but were only depicted as plot points to advance the story without any real investigation.A number of characters also appeared to advance the plot at different points, but brought no further depth to the show. Questions around them were often posed but found no answer. As any amateur writer will tell you, you only ask a question, if you later give the answer.Positive points do exist, but they're mostly external to the writing. There are solid performances (I was especially impressed by Louis Oliver, who plays Ben in the show; his character goes through a rather difficult evolution, but he manages to make it convincing), and the music and photography are well-suited to bring out the dichotomy between the rural, British landscape and the criminal reality of a USA death row; the play of lights, especially, and the intense focus on showing heat and sweat on the prisoners are strong elements to give characters more depth and realism than they probably would with just the dialogue and the story to sustain them.Overall, however, I feel like I came to the show because of David Tennant and stayed exactly for the same reason, so I would not really recommend this show to anyone.

Seriously.... I seriously love Stanley Tucci. He's an incredible actor and I absolutely love everything he is in. Period. While some parts of this story, so far, is incredibly dumb and frustrating, he still makes the show...and I love his character. Super smart. The only reason to watch this is him and his character. The story of the vicor...dumb...just dumb. The other stories are great, just great!! I've only watched 3 episodes so far but I will be disappointed if his story doesn't continue. I feel like there wasn't enough of Stanley and his cunningness so fat. I wish they had shown more of Stanley.

reviews.review_title: Great idea with a huge flaw
reviews.content: Why didnt the clever prisoner in the basement figure out that carbon monoxide was killing her and ask Ben to switch off the heater??? It is a really STUPID flaw in a very interesting concept. All she had to do was say "Ben please turn off the heater" and when it was iver how come Ben not arrested for attempted murder???I thought the acting was really good but it was spoilt by this silliness about the heater for me. Nicely shot and the next silliness is the guy about to be executed still teasing about his wifes head. Its beyond comprehension that this would occur or that the authorities would allow such contact.

reviews.review_title: Don't rate it unless you've watched it!
reviews.content: All of the reviews on here by people who only watched the first episode are pointless. Why would you review something you've only watched a few minutes of?! To be fair, this whole thing is about as far-fetched as you can get, and yes, most of the characters behave in ridiculous and unbelievable ways, but that's the vibe.It's got an almost comical, cartoony element, which I quite enjoyed. It's certainly designed to be funny in parts, which is why the unlikely decisions didn't matter. All of the actors do a great job and have a lot of on-screen charisma.It requires a lot of suspension of disbelief but it's compelling enough. I liked it.

This was different and compelling enough. It reminded me a little of Your Honor (with Brian Cranston), and I liked this somewhat more. In both cases the writing is very heavy-handed. Like packing too many plot elements into a limited series, resulting in an amplified level of drama that stretches the suspension of disbelief a bit too far. I know people are on a big Tucci kick these days, but this is not his best work. He's not BAD, but his performance of this role is nothing more than adequate. He leans into the melodrama, striving unsuccessfully to be as interesting as Anthony Hopkins playing Hannibal Lecter. But I expect he'll get nominations and wins because he's trendy right now. David Tenant is decent. The lesser-known cast is adequate though annoying at moments-that's probably more the writing than acting quality, though. I loved the score for the show, even though it probably contributed to the sense of melodrama, given how intense and persistent it is. I wouldn't NOT recommend the series, for whatever that's worth.

Alone that first seen is so unrealistic. The guy would've had scrambled eggs in no time. This already sets a somewhat disturbing tone. Being a Scorpio like Moffat, I can like dark things and I jumped on, because of the Moffat/Tennant combination. But this stuff has an unhealthy vibe. I watched the first episode without the conviction of turning this on again.Several days passed and I am sitting over the second one now, because I am in the mood to look sth., not totally boring (hard to find) and I like Tennants performance and the suspense build up with Tucci's character (after you hear a case, you want to know what happened - but this is mainly because of nosiness than because of intricate cases). Again, I am annoyed of the general stupidity.So, how could I rate this? 1 point for the acting, 1 point for suspense, - hm, already getting thin now -, it looks quite well, so I can add one more point for that.All in all, I had expected more.

reviews.review_title: Well acted, good plot but unnecessary ending
reviews.content: I actually liked watching the series. Until the ending came. The show is acted well and the plot is interesting to keep one hooked from the first episode. It's intriguing to watch how messed up the situation gets so quickly. That the situations evolves the way it does is portrayed quite plausible. However, I didn't find the end in logical progression with the characters and a bit too constructed. I was also missing some plot twists that I had the feeling were indirectly hinted towards here and there.Also, the self righteous tone in which Mr. Grieff emphasizes that all are murderous got a bit dull after some time. The series tries to demonstrate this. Many questions however are not answered and the audience is left quite unfulfilled.

It's a black comedy, and It's funny how most of the reviewers seem to have missed that.It starts of looking like a typical serial killer dark thriller, with Stanley Tucci as a wife murderer and his creepy but strangely amusing mass-murderer mate, but that is just the start of a real rollercoaster fun ride where everything that can go wrong, does go wrong. The story may be implausible, but it has a point and it never gets boring.Don't believe the bad ratings, relax and enjoy the ride. Tennant in particular is very good as the "sexy vicar," LOL and the rest of the cast do a good job.Wouldn't mind a S2.

I suspect the best story will come from Ben, who goes to a concert and comes home disappointed. I'd watch his whole story, instead of this.10 min in, first episode and you understand you're taken for a fool. Vicar's wife, the character, is as useless as it can get. The guy in prison somehow understands, from a blurry picture, that someone, across the ocean, has a 9:00 PM Skype call. The same guy, in prison, has access to phone calls anytime he pleases. The journalist can fly between US and UK, anytime, trying to write a story she doesn't know anyone might want to read or publish.The vicar is troubled that a pedophile might want to kill himself after being exposed, so he goes to extra lengths to keep him safe, but he's fine with keeping a woman in his cellar, handcuffed to a pipe, covered in wounds (that he does nothing for).Who gave the ok for this? Why?

reviews.review_title: I secound the person who said, what a waste of talent
reviews.content: I really wanted this to be good, but it was just insulting to watch. The plot didn't hold water, because the vicars dilemma was unbelievable from the start. None of the actions of the charcters that led to it made any sense, which rendered the entire show unbelivable and unrelatable. The whole story revolved around this dilemma, from start to finnish, so it being unbeliveable was critical.The story also seemed coarsed, only to hammer in the creator's point, which was repeated over an over again by Stanley Tucci's character, it just felt didcatict. It reminiscent ideas from silence of the lambs, sherlock holmes and a bit of sweeny tod, all done poorly. The writing for Tucci was really bad, he acted like a Sherlock/ Hanibal -knock off, and that's before I knew the creator did Sherlock the tv show as well. He just acted like a pompous know it all, blowing clues in the air for his dummer counterpart, in a really ridiculous way.Over all the show seemed to enjoy toying with the viewer's preception at the expense of making a good story, one that makes sense. The toying part was also contradictory, I'm supposed to identify with the regular man who got sucked into a horrible situation, in order to explore the premis that "every one can be a killer, depending on the situation", yet the woman's behaviour was so unrealistic, it took all the air out of doing so. And I was rationalising her at the beginning.I also hated how they made the serial killer into a cute endearing comic relief, I didn't buy into the attempts of balancing it with mentioning his heinous acts. All the topics the show attempted to handle where done soo poorly, it made me think there's nothing to it but relishing on murderers. It wasn't smart or daring, just fetishising.The cast is fantastic, too bad the weren't used better.

Interesting story, but the most interesting part is never actually resolved. The main story line could have been better. Most of the series it failed to make me care about the characters. The "extremely clever" lady never questioning the mismatch between the kids reaction (or lack there of) to the contents of the flash drive. Like it was no big deal and he claimed it was his without hesitation, that should have been a pretty big indicator that it wasn't his, but she continues to believe it is for most of the series. Also the Vickers reaction should've been a sign that also wasn't right. The writing should have made all that a bit more convincing.

I am not sure why some didn't get this show. It's a very interesting dilemma they find themselves in. Stanley Tucci is perfect as always, dry humor abounds. It's perfectly obvious how all the characters find themselves in all this trouble. Trying to fix it, of course, makes everything much, much worse.The fun of this show is getting you involved in trying to figure out how to get everyone involved out of this mess. And boy...is it a MESS! Pitting everyone against each other...raises the tension. Ben complicates things in the normal, "I'm only trying to help you Dad..duh" way. David Tenant is truely stuck, well and truely stuck. There is no turning back unless you take responsibility for your own part in this huge mess. It only gets worse the more they twist. A very fun and interesting idea!

reviews.review_title: If you eat pieces of s#*t for breakfast, this show is for you!
reviews.content: I only gave this two stars because I love Stanley Tucci. It deserves none. Basically many peoples lives are ruined because a math tutor with an inflated self image doesn't have the cognitive ability to process more than one thought per situation. To elaborate, a tragedy occurs, there could be many reasons as to why or how this has happened. But good ole Janice (Math tutor) can only see the first thought that comes into her tiny brain and is incapable of adapting to literally any new information she receives and takes everyone down with her. Every second she's on screen I thank god that I don't have anyone in my life remotely close to Janice's personality. I was rooting for her death after the first few minutes of the first episode. I vow to start a Janice hating club in my free time after watching this series. Dm me if interested.

Looks good, but David Tenant is not what I expext thr language is dreadful no clergyman would speak bad words or behave in that way.I will still watch it but so far it's ridiculous and too far fetched from reality, it's beyond belief how the character is being portrayed. The actions don't add up or stack up either, it's a pity as this somewhat ruins the story.I'm only on the first episode so find this to be really daft, I hope it redeems itself and gets better later on I'm not holding out much hope.To be honest I'm. Not a fan of tenent style of acting. He was good in Harry Potter but this is silly,

reviews.review_title: How much disbelief do I need to suspend?
reviews.content: I was quite excited to watch this because I expected a smart, slick British crime drama like Broadchurch, which also starred David Tennat. But even though this mini-series tries its hardest to impersonate being clever, it's clumsy and falls flat on its face.Dr. Grieff and his sidekick are far from intimidating or cunning, despite Grieff's confidence and calm. The repetitive dialogue undermined any cleverness I could've felt. The tone and pacing are bizarre. I had to watch it on 1.25x speed by the second episode because the slow pacing, probably meant to stew tension, was just maddening to watch. Just because it's tense doesn't mean it's good!Things the characters say contradict what is apparent on the screen and we're just supposed to go along with it? For instance, Grieff's sidekick remarks that he can tell Grieff likes the journalist based off his verbosity, but to the viewer it seems like he just talked as he normally does. If it's going to be surreal, that's okay, but make it entertaining. This is just surreal without any of the fun.

reviews.review_title: Keeps you watching but you feel dirty doing so
reviews.content: There are enough hooks to keep you watching but in the end I felt like I bought into something horrible and am lesser for it. This is a story of a good family destroyed by their own charity. It has a very dark and nihilistic theme, that there is evil in all of us and we are just one bad day from committing heinous acts. Do we want to live in a world where this is the norm, where shows like this are allowed to peddle this filth? You could say that it's just Hollywood or entertainment but I think we create the world in which we live by our actions and choices. I truly wish I hadn't watched this. I can't unsee it but if you have not started it yet, save yourself.

reviews.review_title: Could have been great, nonsense towards kills it
reviews.content:
Starts off gripping and intriguing but by episode 4, gets very silly in Parts. I did find Lyndsey marshal's character annoying and misplaced from the beginning, but in the last episode , she is beyond ridiculous. Maybe it's the writers trying to be quirky, but it doesn't work. Stanley Tucci and David Tennant are great as usual. It just feels messy and like it doesn't know what it is, a thriller or comedy.For the show to be so good for it's 3
Episode, then too let a few Silly moments let it down is quite annoying.I would definitely watch a second series, I would just hope the writers take onboard viewer feedback, because many have been annoyed by the same parts.

reviews.review_title: This could be great a show but...
reviews.content: Everything is great about this show: idea, characters, acting, it's funny, combination of 2 story's, etc. , etc.I liked watching all 4 episodes. Great acting en super dialogues. Some lines of the mean character I've even had to wrote down. Also the side stories are very funny. So far so good. I'll gave it 8 stars.But the plotholes you fall in are far too big. That's a pity. I'am a flexible viewer en most of the time can I stap over the gab, but after the 3 episode of total of 4. You lost me. Sorry.I hope there will be a next show with a better plot.I can't wait. So writers do a better job and you get 8 stars.

This mini series will make you want to pull your hair out in frustration. Not worth it. The first episode has its moments and might hook you (as it did me), but save yourself the time and seek something else. I was drawn in as a huge fan of Sherlock, but this is no where near that masterpiece; quite the contrary, it's terrible. 4 stars only because it's not the worst thing I've seen and the casting was solid. From beginning to end, you will find yourself questioning the decisions of the main characters and may even consider screaming at your television. There has to be something else on Netflix you haven't seen to spend your time more wisely.

THIS IS THE BEST SHOW I HAVE EVER SEEN IN MY LIFE!Brilliant plot, amazing acting!Couldn't be more realistic, it puts you in the position of the protagonist and makes you share the same feelings.The plot was riveting.I have never felt such agony before and the most exciting thing is that you did not expect what would happen the next moment.Between these four episodes the creator showed in the best way that each of us can be in a similar position and does such actions because the circumstances led him there. As the show says, only one bad day is enough. Dark and at the same time humorous, realistic, true to life, it sends many messages about man and his nature and what he is capable of doing to protect what he loves.Steven Moffat thank you for what you created!

reviews.review_title: Mourish cast performance decapitated by a bamboozling plot
reviews.content: The series slowly pulls you in as the characters descend down an outlandish plot line. Tense and gripping in parts along with an intriguing portrayal by Tucci on death row. However the series is hindered by a befuddled escalation of the central situation and unreleastic character reactions.The issue here feels as though the script has intended to emulate blockbuster thrillers like 'The Usual Suspects' yet been adulterated by the cost of living crisis. Plot hole ambiguity leave viewers doubting the mastermind behind the writing and death row detective. Pantomime irony leeches your eyeballs for the next ebbing.

reviews.review_title: Entertaining, there's some suspense, obviously top notch cast :p
reviews.content: If you can force your suspense of disbelief to some extent (I get that's kinda missing the point of tbh shows for some) you get a pretty interesting show. Yes, how the vicar gets into the whole mess is a bit silly but afterwards when the snowball effect moves in it actually made sense. I can watch David Tennant in anything and love it so I might be subjective here. I do think there's a lot of originality to this show, characters have some depth (though it's not like an insane amount or anything), no one is fully likeable which I personally enjoyed and I could definitely feel the suspense many times. I would totally watch a show about two death row inmates solving crimes, that was probably the best part :) I think it's worth a watch, it's no masterpiece but defo entertaining!

reviews.review_title: How did it fit into 4 episodes?
reviews.content: A seriously black tale of loose threads and vague characters. After one episode, it felt impossible that the story unfolding could be told and concluded in just three more instalments.Stanley Tucci plays a highly intelligent character - which is almost his typecast persona - on death row in the US, filling in his days solving crimes for which he is totally equipped, despite his unusual predicament.On the other side of the Atlantic is a disconnect of characters playing out a real-time, crime drama.Allow yourself two hours for episode three; you will not want to stop watching this series until the messy conclusion.

Longest four episodes I've watched in a long time. Not long time wise but just extremely slow and annoying.The main character's actions are unrealistic and irrational. The other guy in jail just tries too hard to find off as cool with his riddles and smirk. Then there's the serial killer in jail that the writers are trying to get us to like because he's the funny black guy. The tutor who is supposed to be smart but doesn't realize she's been so clearly wrong from the beginning. Then the post credit scene that makes everything up until now not matter and also is just a lame cliff hanger to trying and get a new season made. I didn't realize how bad the show was until episode 2 so i figured I'd just have to survive 2 more episodes to get the conclusion and found it a huge waste of time. Good thing i cooked and did other stuff as the episodes were just fluff and non sensible actions by the main characters.

Only watched the first so far (and may be the only one I watch) but I just feel like it's way over the top and doesn't make sense. David Tennant, who is a vicar, somehow manages to assault and kidnap a friend to protect his son from being falsely accused of something even though he knows the true culprit. Surely going the police station with item and said friend and then telling them who the person is and letting them investigate is better than now going to prison for assault and kidnapping?! It just escalated too quickly for something so stupid. The only saving grace to me is the Stanley Tucci side of it which seems more interesting but not enough to watch more. Maybe if i get desperate.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, plot holes and long unneeded dialogue
reviews.content: I didn't mind the potential plot here, but the dialogue scenes with the Vicar and his wife, SHOULD of been shortened. I've never seen such long dialogue scenes just repeating themselves, . As many have mentioned about the plot holes. In the first place any reasonable person would realise that you need more evidence for the plot to go this way. Then be ok I guess.. as a 2 hr movie, cut out some of the stupid scenes.Stanley Tucci was great. I'm unsure of his sidekick of what he was doing but whatever.Loved Janice's character. But yes this could of been a 2hr movie after some cuts of useless scenes.

This appears to be yet another show in the Netflix factory line. Throw in some of the actors that can typically draw an audience and then squander their talents. Secondly. The attempt at wedging in humor to the vile act of murder is in poor taste. And done poorly. I'm sure the production was rushed. Also the music choice is terrible. If you have ever seen the episode on Portlandia about music in television. This is it incarnate. As mentioned before that it's just filler until they come out with a blockbuster once a year to secure subscriptions. They would have done a better service making a series about the movie Inside Man. But. I'm not on the salary. So what do I know.

reviews.review_title: Gripping premise... rubbish ending. Wish he'd used our ending!
reviews.content: Totally preposterous, and yet gripping. But ultimately disappointing because the end didn't have any great reveal, or twist or even proper resolution. It just ended rather meekly. My partner came up with a much better ending before we started episode 4. Stanley Tucci didnt murder his wife at all - instead she had done something dreadful which he was covering for by pretending to murder her - hence the mutilated body and no head - and she had moved to England and became Janice Fife! Janice was actually a psychopath and would get out of the cellar killing David Tennant and Stanley Tucci would somehow cover for her again! Actual ending was rubbish!

Fine acting, as the cast, including Atkins and West who were new to me-try hard to persuade the viewer that they're impersonating real people in something resembling the real world. The opening sequence is smart and skillful, and raised my hopes for the rest--I mean, how can you go wrong with Stanley Tucci and David Tennant? Yet the writers manage it. OK, I'll suspend my disbelief but I don't have enough rope to suspend it as high as this script, which piles up the implausibilities as it goes on, demands. The cast try this impossible assignment, and no blame to them for failing. Wait: why not a series with Tucci's and Atkins' characters playing private eyes? "Dillon and Grieff, Affordable Investigators: We never leave the office!"

Stephen Moffat, Stanley Tucci, David Tennant... this should be my favourite project in theory. The team, the talent, the wonderful cinematography SHOULD make for remarkable entertainment and thought provoking television.But alas this was an astronomical waste of my time. My partner couldn't get past two episodes; I deeply regret watching till the end. It never got better, in fact it got significantly worse (somehow). I got nothing from this show, the script was overwritten and the plot was painfully convoluted.Do not watch, save the precious hours in your life to read a good book or take a class, I feel like I lost brain cells watching this show.Giving it three stars as it's nice they tried to make something new and experimented with new material, which is important. But this was a miss and a hug waste of the immense talent both in front of and behind the camera.

reviews.review_title: The reviews here are proof "user ratings" are completely irrelevant
reviews.content:
This show was brilliant. Well worth a watch for "something different"
Tennant and Tucci are such great actors.... Well worth a look even just for their brilliant acting.The reviews and ratings here are living proof that most people are actually stupid and that this show went over the top of most people's heads. Gathering that the majority of people who have seen this is your average Netflix viewer ... The negative reviews come as no surprise. (go take a look at the Netflix catalogue of what's available to watch. Their brains are completely fried)Dear Netflix viewer,
Please stop leaving bad reviews and low ratings for shows you're too simple to understand. You're absolutely not qualified enough to be reviewing such things.

reviews.review_title: Not realistic, but strong and fun story
reviews.content: Normally i do not watch below an imdb score of 7. Due to steven moffat i started with the trailer. I know steven from doctor who and sherlock homes series. Most of the series give me alot of joy watching. For me i give inside man a solid 8. Story really "sucked me in", was well written and i was really wandering how the story would end. For sure not realistic, had alot of fun watching. Its also a serie to watch together, my wife enjoyed it for sure. Only the last minute, as a cliff hanger to the second season, could have been better. Even though i cannot wait and im hoping on a second season to come any time soon.

Very pointless and senseless storyline. In real life these conversations don't happen like this. I get the point at the end where Stanley Tucci's character says to David Tennant's character is now an inside man, but I think it didn't require these happenings. It was another crazy, but worthless to see series from Netflix and the only good thing is Stanley Tucci. He is brilliant and the only reason I have watched little from this one. I don't recommend to anyone to watch this, instead people should see more documentarys, informative and exciting movies, where people can really learn and become more smart.

I love Stanley Tucci and David Tennant but this story line is ridiculous! The best scenes are with Jefferson and Dillon which aren't enough. The rest is just stupid. The actions taken by everyone involved are beyond the scope of reason. I'm sure this is supposed to be about the lengths people will go to protect themselves but come on!!! A load of sad delusional idiots. Janices inability to hear the truth is at the crux of the whole story. She jumps to her own conclusion and that seals her fate. She's unlikable and lonely and pathetic. That's more than I wanted to say but there's a character limit.

The show starts off good and promising. Gets questionable in the first episode. Still intrigued though so kept watching.The two different parts were good. Was hoping they could come back from the beginning story line and make it better. Didn't happen.I can't believe I watched the whole thing.Why in the world would these actors agree to this show? It makes no sense. Why would a person ruin their entire family and others for a pedi? I don't get it. The guy ruins his life for no reason. The end was terrible. Don't waste your time.And still didn't answer all the questions. Could have finished.

This show has some really stupid parts, but if you can get past those and watch with an open mind, you will see the point that they are trying to make which is: "Very few people wake up in the morning and plan on committing an atrocious crime, but 99% of the time- that's exactly what happens and all of the sudden, life changes forever". That's the story behind the Vicar and his family as one minute they are living the dream with a perfect life and the next, they are living a nightmare that keeps spinning out of control as they try to make a "wrong" "right". Yes, it seems far fetched, but in reality, we have all read of the great lengths that people have gone through in order to "cover their tracks".. THIS is what this is about and once you watch with that mindset, you will be able to
accept the "far fetched" parts as real possibilities.. Looking forward to more episodes of this mind twisting drama...

The story wasn't bad but the failure to communicate or listen in scripts has always irritated me . The whole issue could have been resolved in five minutes if someone had taken the time to listen and talk it out and the "victim: frankly is difficult to empathize with at all . So I ended up rooting for the so called "villain" through the entire season .Overall though the ending was tolerable . I thought the acting was great and the sequence of events kept me on the edge of my seat . Im still very curious about Stanley Tuccis characters backstory so they have it primed for a potential season 2 .

The idea of the show is very promising: all it takes is one bad day. I can get behind that. I woud love to see how an obviously adorable character can take a series of bad decisions to find themselves in a tight corner, a point of no return. You start by feeling bad for the guy and at the end, you despise him but not without a pang of sadness, or maybe a small voice inside your head: what would I do in their position? That's where the show lost me.Because when I position myself in the protagonist's head, I can find seemingly obvious choices that could quite easily avoid everything they went through! This is where I started to feel like the writers were a bit lazy and I didn't like that.The castings were perfect. Stanley Tucci as the death row detective and David Tennant as the troubles Vicar nailed their characters in every respect. The visuals were stunning, although some shots felt repititive where there were opportunities to be more creative. I wish the story had a little more depth and the writers covered all the obvious choices or argued against them more convincingly.I binged the whole thing. It was a fun show and would recommend to anyone looking for a new limited series, but will probably forget about it in a few weeks.

reviews.review_title: Lightly entertaining thriller with insultingly contrived writing.
reviews.content: I'm someone who typically enjoys Moffat's writing and predictably I found the basic writing mechanics of the story enjoyable. I also choose willingly to watch this through to the end so I would argue that there's think there's some version of this story that might have worked (everyone's a murderer, crime-solving detective on death row, Vicar torn between his religious convictions and protecting his son yadda yadda). What I unfortunately can't look past however is how fundamentally and completely unbelievable the story is. Unbelievable is even too weak a word with a story that takes place in an unapologetically cartoon-like universe where the plot in large part revolves around a door that has been assigned by the writer the magical property of not propagating any sound (not even through it's keyhole that is later explicitly tapped over as part of the plot). The character's decisions feel like they were chosen by a machine learning algorithm programmed to select out of all possible decisions whichever would maximise the length of the plot and I would say that reflects the precise strategy Steven wrote this story with. This story is formulated, not crafted. It's like how some when some AI's reach a no-win scenario, they keep playing because haven't been programmed with respect for the opponent's intelligence and that's really the fundamental problem with this story. It doesn't realise that its audience have a higher standard of realism than what it's aiming for. There are a number of moments in this story that considered in isolation are so completely ridiculous that it boggles belief as to how Steven didn't realised that he must have written something incredibly silly to get there.I might have given this a 6/10 if a moment towards the end of the final episode hadn't made me actively angry when a character fundamentally fails to redeem themself or even shown the barest amount of intelligence in learning from their own mistakes.

reviews.review_title: The suspension of disbelief can only take you so far.
reviews.content: With a cast just filling to the brim in talent this show should've been amazing. But lazy writing decisions to advance this already hard to believe plot just makes this whole show horrific to watch. If the Tutor had just remained calm and didn't go completely nutty. While yes, it would be a startling discovery, any investigation would've proved innocence of the Vicar. The introduction of the plot is just all around horrendous. And it only gets worse. Stanley Tucci's character is a a bigger Mary Sue than Sherlock and Batman. At least they use logic and have the materials needed to make those leaps in conclusions. Sending people to places at exact times, running a secret inside prison fbi level? Come on. The Reporter not calling 911 when the Wife cut her? It's just idiocy. She mocked the lady with the knife, at her missing friends apartment that's the reason the whole story exists a. So she could run into traffic and kill herself?. DUMB. I'm a firm believer in the suspension of disbelief, but it can only take you so far. And with every plot point just becoming more and more unbelievable it seems like this whole story is a crumbling tower of Jenga blocks trying to play a game of jenga in another jenga tower, equally falling apart. The only good scene is when the Vicar helped Edgar. Of course he's a dirtbag, and deserves what he got, however. If the story had maintained that projectory, it would've easily been Emmy Worthy. Forget the whole Prison thing, make Stanley Tucci an American PI Who goes to the church. Or hell, Stanley Tucci could ace any role given to him, make him whoever. The investigative journalist could interview the new PI character, and the point of the Vicar crossing that line of becoming a murderer (which he doesn't do) because of him going through a bad day would actually pay off. Also Dillon is the best character. David Tenant did well for what he was given to work with. The wife was entertaining at times. The tutor was good except for being the reason the awful story escalated the way it did. All the actors did well. But the story and direction was big doo doo. 5/10.

This story doesn't seem to know what it is aiming for or who it is aimed at. The only people who seem to find allegory in it are a few members of the clergy or ex members I have spoken with who's experiences with major religions have left them with buttons to be pushed which this series did. That in itself should be worrying but the story line doesn't really touch on that aspect of things. As a comment on 'even the best of us can make terrible decisions', the story was completely unbelievable for me to take seriously. Not just one main character doing really stupid things but several others being liars, thoughtless, reactionary and lacking any kind of moral compass. Honestly, I found it difficult to believe anyone would sign up to undertake a script like this in the first place.

reviews.review_title: Started off great then became annoying
reviews.content: This started off looking really good then quickly down spiralled Only got a 2 star for the part in America this was super annoying and could not wait for it to end. Worst thing I've ever seen David Tennant in. Pathetic, completely unbelievable and unnecessary.Ended up screaming at the TV as it was winding me up so much, decision making similar to the decisions and desisiveness of Mr Bean for everyone involved in the UK part.I highly suggest that you avoid wasting your time on this mini series and I really, really hope they do not bring out a second season! Saying that the part played by the "Inside man" worked well and could be expanded on.

I didn't check the rating and reviews before watching it and I'm actually surprised it's rated so low.I loved every second, it's an original story with a modern Sherlock Holmes-like character on death row.I liked the unpredictability, you never know what happens next and it keeps you on edge. The length was appropriate, watching it felt like a longer movie.It ends on a cliffhanger, so I hope that means more episodes or a new mini season. If not, then the ending is a bit disappointing, as it contradicts the information we know about one of the characters.I love how it it's trying to show how anyone's life can go off the rails unexpectedly and how one little decision sets off a chain of bad choices. We all think "that'll never be me" but that's exactly what the vicar thought too, so you never know.Definitely recommend it!

reviews.review_title: Frustrating, implausible that made very little sense
reviews.content: I found this so frustrating and so full of holes. I am annoyed that I watched it until the end but had convinced myself that there would be some great twist at the end, which would pull it all together. I was wrong. It was left with so many open endings that I can only assume was a desperate way to get a 2nd season. No reason explanation why Janice was so awful, no explanation as to why the convict chopped his wife's head off 'once you find her head you'll know why I killed her'. That wasn't explained. Why did the convict have a serial killer with him as his helper. As for the main plot.....one of the worst things I've seen for a while and if a 2nd season is made I will not give it my time. I get the moral if the story but the story itself is beyond weak, overly complicated and doesn't tie together. If it was a straight up black comedy it may have work.

reviews.review_title: 3 Great episodes lead to a swing and miss finale
reviews.content:
I must say I love the characters of this show, they are all funny, witty, original people that will say and do original things.This show very much subscribes to the writing trope that you can have random happenstance cause the problems for your characters and I can understand people not liking it, but I loved the first three episodes. Yes, dumb things happen in real life and people will make dumb choices under duress.It's just that last episode that is a complete mess for me. A couple of the highlights of what make this last episode a terrible writing masterclass:
-Gas Leak Poisoning makes you murder a woman
-Scene where a person runs into the street in a panic and gets hit by a car
-Phone calls where simply saying some words would have solved all problems.The conclusion of it all: "Anyone can be a murderer" is super weak and it would have been more surprising if the conclusion was that they decided not to go through with it and that leading to Tucci having to review his own choices. Because anyone CAN become a murderer, but it is a choice they make.It was such a miss for me this last episode, while I loved the rest. I even loved the little teaser on the end, I want to know more about Tucci's character and if there would be more I'd watch it.But all-in-all it just never got to a good conclusion and these characters were so strong, that when they act out of character it sticks out as a sore thumb:-Tenant never was dispicable enough to give that rant he gives at the end, it just felt out of character.Pfife is smart enough to realize that when the son keeps being completely surprised by her reaction to the porn, that the vicar might have been telling the truth, same for the reason he would let her listen to the suicide note, would that not be a crazy thing to do if you expect it to go the way it went.-The mom basically becomes a bad comedy trope in the last episode.It's all so freaking bad, like someone had a stroke writing the last episode. I dunno, I usually don't review a lot, but this left me so frustrated that I had to leave a review, because this could have been great.

reviews.review_title: Completely unbelievable premise but I loved it anyway!
reviews.content: The plot starts off really well - Stanley Tucci is great as the Death Row criminologist helping solve a missing person's case and who couldn't love David Tennant as the vicar caught in a moral quandary? The two stories begin side by side and then begin to intertwine in unexpected ways. The supporting cast is also really strong - especially Lindsey Marshal as Tennant's wife and Dolly Wells as the clever math tutor who thinks she can use her intellect to maneuver her way out of a tough spot. Put aside the plausibility issues and just enjoy the ride. And spend some time pondering the idea that we could all be murderers given the right circumstances. The last 15 minutes is a nail biter!

It's really confusing.. this series should have been two separate ones..one is exciting and the other is really stupid!! I mean the killer in America seems a good story they should invest in THAT story and produce a solid series instead of this rubbish about the obnoxious person trapped in a cellar in the UK. The story is weak they didn't need all that drama. Simply they could've let her go she didn't has any prove , she could go to police and they can search the house, the church everywhere I mean what the hill is that all about. I frustrated and bored and I kept forwarding I wanted it to end.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good with lots of implicit meaning
reviews.content: Yes some of the storyline is unrealistic and presents events that wouldn't happen in real life. However, the premise of the show is that anyone can be a murderer. Even the vicar can contemplate murder. And rationalise it by believing he has the right authority to act in that way to achieve 'the greater good'. With elements of 'sacrifice' in many forms along the way. In that context, it's a good show and it gets the point across. The way the two storylines are connected works really well. However I'm still hanging on to where Stanley Tucci's character's wife is, why he killed her and how she is in any way connected to Janice?!

As many others have said, what a waste of talent! The plot is so totally implausible in so many aspects. The banter between the two men on death row is by far the most enjoyable part And they are 2 of the very few likable characters. The serious flaws were apparent very early on but I kept watching hoping it would somehow improve. I did not understand the ending either. How is Janice talking to him about killing her husband? What husband? Was that a flashback? I'm so confused! Did we ever find out if Stanley was being honest about the location of his wife's head? Obviously I was playing too much pokemon go and candy crush and wasn't paying much attention lol.

First couple of episodes, I was completely hooked, on the edge of my seat, right up until the last episode. Then the characters started to annoy me, I wasn't nearly as invested and the interesting link between Stanley tucci's character and the main story got further and further away.David Tennant, Stanley Tucci and Lyndsey Marshal all gave great performances. However they couldn't save the over the top, melodramatic techniques, shots and script used. The twist and turns started to look cheap and unnecessary just to add shock value. A shame as the series up to the climatic sequence was such an interesting concept.

Probably the worst show I've seen in a while, especially considering how excited I got, seeing names like Moffat, Tennant and Tucci.The plot makes absolutely no sense, mainly the fact that the vicar chooses to protect one unstable character over the lives of his own family members and of course, children who are being exploited and harmed.The Tucci character felt almost like a completely different show. Side characters are so bad to the point of being comical. Don't even get me started on the "whoosh whoosh" knife scene towards the end...Gotta admit with some other viewers that this show feels like an insult to viewers.Gave it 2 stars for the performances of Stanley Tucci and David Tennant.

The entire show doesn't make sense from beginning to end. Truly terrible and I'm angry at myself for watching all 4 episodes. I can't get that time back.I'm still trying to understand how anyone wrote this and thought it was good? Not a single part of the story was plausible. The acting were terrible (which is so sad because I adore Stanley Tucci).The entire time I Was left wondering WHY the vicar continued this absurd lie. Why not get rid of the thumb drive as soon as he knew what was on it? Why take the blame knowing the other person would be free to continue doing what he was- that is twisted.

The trailer hooked me right away. Stanley Tucci and David Tennant? Kinda makes it a must watch! We settled in for a casual viewing and didn't come up for air until the end of the series 4 hours later. It was seemingly very light-hearted and clever. But like any great tragedy, the best intentions of the characters only served to entangle them in a disaster that never should have happened. Much more deeply unsettling for me than other tragedies I have watched. Incredibly well executed, with twists and turns that shock and amaze, but also savage punches to the gut. For me, easily a 9-star caliber work and hats off to Stephen Moffat, a criminal mastermind indeed. The reason for taking off three stars for me was the emotional wreckage (mine) left behind.

If you were looking for high drama, guess again. If you were looking for a sophisticated crime caper, this is not that. If you were looking for a first-rate suspense thriller, it won't be found here. If you, however, recognize a black comedy when you see it, then welcome home! The story line is purposefully implausible, the acting very broad, and the writers go so far in frequently reminding us it is a comedy - it just is not filled with one-liners, sight gags, and slapstick. Tennant, Tucci, Baker, and Lyndsey Marshal are in rare form, with Dolly Wells a superb straight man. For those who stuck with it through all four episodes, I hope you enjoyed it as much as I did. Simply terrific.

Gave him that usb stick to hold on to for him.THIS CAN ALL BE SOLVED IN 5 MINUTES
They managed to stretch this over 4 episodes.The only redeeming characteristic of this show is the acting. But I often found myself yelling at the TV because these characters watched 1 episode of CSI.But the incredulous demeanor of all the characters towards the incident drove me insane.

Stick with it. The last episode, Hell the last 10 minutes pulls it all together. And watch after the credits. Fine acting all around. David Tennant, Dolly Wells, Lydia West, Lyndsey Marshal, and Stanley Tucci all gave excellent performances.my favorite character came from Atkins Estimond, his character of Dillion had me laughing in almost every scene. It doesn't need seem to make any sense but in the end it does. I really enjoyed the story. Stephen Moffat's scripts always entertain. If you were the vicar, What would you do? So take it from there and realize the vicar has himself in a bad situation.

reviews.review_title: Did they just make a new genre... thriller/comedy... a Thromedy?
reviews.content: You gotta just roll with it being completely implausible and realize it was written this way. When you do, you'll see the humor and the brilliance of it. The build up from each episode is done very well. It starts out being very serious, and slowly you start questioning the writers and what the heck they were thinking, until for me in the 3rd episode you're ready to just give up on it and turn it off, when it clicks.... And now you just wanna watch this train wreck all the way through. Basically, whatever a normal rational human being would decide to do given the circumstances.... The characters will just do the opposite. It's definitely not predictable!
